title: Travellers barred from whole towns Draconian laws used in new crackdown
story: The &ldquoblanket injunctions, which mean anyone pulling up on affected sites can be arrested, jailed or fined, can effectively ban travellers from entire boroughs.Councils applying for the orders have given the High Court witness statements and photographs of commercial waste, including asbestos, excrement and damaged locks from vacated sites.Previously, councils have reacted to traveller incursions, but they can now outlaw them before they happen.Nearly 20 authorities across London, Essex, Hampshire, Surrey, the West Midlands and Lancashire now have interim or blanket injunctions, with more believed to be preparing applications.                Traveller crackdown: Tory MPs urge new law to move camps on QUICKLY                Travellers leave rubbish and human FAECES in children's play areaGipsy and traveller organisations have slammed the new power, claiming it will prevent their nomadic way of life.Sarah Sweeney of Friends, Families and Travellers said: &ldquoWe are deeply saddened to hear that increasing numbers of councils are using injunctions to prevent gipsy and traveller families from stopping in their area.&ldquoLocal authorities have largely failed to identify land for families to stop so it should come as little surprise when they pull up in public spaces and on private land.A spokesman for the Community Law Partnership, which has represented travellers for several years, said: &ldquoWe think these wide injunction actions, which are becoming more common, are potentially highly challengeable.Caravans in a M&ampS car park in Camberley, Surrey (Image: STEVE REIGATE)London Borough Sutton is the latest to obtain the power, following a series of costly clean-ups after incursions in recent weeks.The High Court has granted an interim injunction order for three months, banning caravans from 182 sites, before a full application is heard.The injunctions ban named iniduals and &ldquopersons unknown from parking caravans and vehicles and dumping waste in areas they cover.If all councils were granted the power, it could effectively see an end to the bulk of unauthorised camps.Harlow council in Essex, which has two permanent traveller sites, was the first to get the ban, protecting 322 sites, in March 2015, after 109 incursions in 18 months.Council leader Mark Ingall said: &ldquoThis has had the effect of significantly reducing the number and duration of unauthorised encampments and the clean-up costs.It quickly resolves any issues, usually within 24 hours.Basildon in Essex secured one last November and councillor Kevin Blake said: &ldquoThere has been a marked reduction in the number of encampments with no incursions since March this year.20 authorities now have interim or blanket injunctions (Image:  )Greenwich in South-east London now has 203 parks and open spaces protected.A spokeswoman said: &ldquoIt has been hugely successful. There has only been one incursion since the ban was put in place.Redbridge, in east London, saw 40 incursions in 2007.But since securing an interim injunction in June, covering 235 sites, it has seen just one incident on council land, with culprits moved on within two hours, and another on private land.

title: A church on every estate
story: The project is backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury (Image: )A church on every estate in the UK is the ambitious new vision of the Church of England.The project, backed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, will see residents on large estates receive help to set up and lead the new churches.It aims to bring Christianity and church life to communities which might not otherwise attend standard services &ndash and help tackle the rise in violent crime.Community centres, cafes and schools will be used as bases for worshippers to meet.                Fury as Archbishop of Canterbury hails European Union in new speech                 Archbishop of Canterbury says HIGHER taxes should fund NHS Thriving church estates have already sprung up around the UK and church leaders say they build stronger communities.The Bishop of Burnley, Philip North, chairman of the Archbishops&rsquo Estates Evangelism Task Force, said: &ldquoThe vision is a thriving, loving Christian church on every single large estate. &ldquoThat&rsquos not a building &ndash we&rsquore talking about church as community of people.&ldquoSometimes it will be in a church building, but often it might be in a community centre or in a school or a large cafe. &ldquoThat&rsquos the vision a thriving Christian community on every estate.Estate residents will be trained to lead the churches, including the possibility of ordination.The project is part of the CofE&rsquos expecting people to come to us but for us to go to them.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime by creating strong communities. &ldquoWhat the church does best is to build community and to build places where you can form a safe relationship.&ldquoWe can&rsquot solve those big cultural problems, but what we can do is offer iniduals spaces of safety and belonging where they can turn their lives around. That&rsquos where local churches are at their best.&ldquoWe talk the language of hope and we can answer some of these questions.People from all backgrounds can lead on estates, but if you want to plant a new church, that&rsquos best  (Image: )Bishop Thorpe said: &ldquoChurches on estates are close to those who live on estates.They are often the first to know about issues with young people and support young people. &ldquoAs Christians, we believe that God wants everyone to discover a relationship with him through Jesus Christ.So we need to go to every place, which includes places that many people don&rsquot go to, like estates.Speaking about one successful estate church in the north of England, Bishop North said: &ldquoOne of the key leaders in that church was addicted to heroin for 23 years and he gave it up when he found this church.&ldquoI asked him why and he said, &lsquoBecause I found somewhere where I felt safe&rsquo.You&rsquore seeing lives turned round and that&rsquos very exciting for church leaders.Renewal and Reform strategy.Bishop North said: &ldquoThe best person to plant a church on an estate is someone from that estate.                Demise of Christianity: Haunting pictures show abandoned churches                The vicar's wife secret affair forced them to quitPeople from all backgrounds can lead on estates, but if you want to plant a new church, that&rsquos best done by a local person.&ldquoIt&rsquos about identifying local leaders with those skills and training them up. We&rsquore encouraging churches to identify local people from estates with the skills to plant new churches.&ldquoThe Archbishop of Canterbury started an Evangelism Task Group about five or six years ago.We have said that this will only work if we are serious about the urban church and what&rsquos going on the estates.&ldquoA church which abandons poor areas is not the church of Jesus Christ.So we worked very hard to get that &lsquoestates voice&rsquo heard. &ldquoArchbishop was very, very up for that and really understood what we were saying.The Bishop of Islington, Ric Thorpe, is leading a project to grow new churches in London.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime  (Image: )He said: &ldquoCouncil estates are places that are sometimes cut off from the rest of a parish.Where a couple of generations ago people attended the local church from the estate, now less and less attend.&ldquoRather than expecting them to come to the parish church, we should go to them.Bishop Thorpe, who is on the team of Capital Vision 2020 &ndash creating 100 new worshipping communities by 2020 &ndash added: &ldquoThis is the call of the church through the ages, like the incarnation of Jesus, not expecting people to come to us but for us to go to them.Bishop North believes the presence of a church on an estate can address the issue of violent crime by creating strong communities.&ldquoWhat the church does best is to build community and to build places where you can form a safe relationship. &ldquoWe can&rsquot solve those big cultural problems, but what we can do is offer iniduals spaces of safety and belonging where they can turn their lives around. That&rsquos where local churches are at their best.&ldquoWe talk the language of hope and we can answer some of these questions.Bishop Thorpe said: &ldquoChurches on estates are close to those who live on estates.They are often the first to know about issues with young people and support young people.&ldquoAs Christians, we believe that God wants everyone to discover a relationship with him through Jesus Christ.So we need to go to every place, which includes places that many people don&rsquot go to, like estates. story: Greek diplomat Dimitris Caramitsos-Tziras issued a stern warning to the UK claiming there would be serious economic consequences for both Britain and Greece in the event of a Brexit no deal.The ambassador suggested that failing to reach an agreement with the European Union could impact some impacts of Greek-British relations, including vitally&nbspimportant tourism.&nbspSpeaking to the Today programme, Mr Caramitson-Tziras said: The possibility of a no deal, and I think everyone should be prepared for that, for any eventuality anyway.It may affect some aspects of Greek-British relations that have an economic impact like tourism, like transportation and a few direct investments. title: brexit news latest UK no deal WTO Iain Duncan Smith
story: In the online video posted to Twitter on behalf of the Brexit campaign group #StandUp4Brexit, the Tory MP rejected suggestions that the UK is heading towards a &lsquono deal&rsquo scenario, claiming that &ldquothere is no such thing as a no deal scenario and that &ldquothere will be a deal, even if it means accepting the Prime Minister&rsquos controversial Chequers deal.The former Tory leader slammed Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposal calling it &ldquothe worst of all worlds but said that fears over a &lsquono-deal&rsquo Brexit were unfounded, as a return to World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules would still govern our trading relationship with the EU.He said: &ldquoStrong democracies with strong democratic institutions, accountable to their people almost always end up being good, peaceful, cooperative nations. And that&rsquos why now we need more than ever to stand up for Brexit.&ldquoHaving had that vote in 2016, where the British people gave their opinion, a binding opinion, we now see another onslaught of yet again Project Fear.                Iain Duncan Smith explains exactly what the Brussels bloc SHOULD do                IDS says Carney &lsquogot it WRONG&rsquo as he attacks &lsquopanicking&rsquo markets&ldquoAll the same organisations, now moving their adjustment and their sights, saying &lsquowe didn&rsquot really mean it was going to happen straight after the vote, we actually meant that it would happen of you didn&rsquot have a deal. A no-deal scenario&rsquoMr Duncan-Smith continued: &ldquoWell, there is no such thing as a no deal scenario. There will be a deal. Whether it&rsquos the deal that&rsquos on the table from Chequers, which I don&rsquot agree with at all because it binds us into the European Union. We will be rule takers rather than rule makers, which is pretty much the worst of all worlds.&ldquoBut that notwithstanding, even if we were to go without a free trade arrangement, and I prefer a standard free trade arrangement, but if we aren&rsquot able to get that and we have to go to the World Trade Organisation, we should recognise that this is a rules based organisation that governs the very arrangements within the EU themselves and its relationships, in trading term, with other nations around the world.&nbspSo the WTO is not a &lsquono deal&rsquo, it&rsquos just a different deal.Brexit latest: Former Tory leader Iain Duncan-Smith has slammed the Prime Minister's Chequers deal (Image: StandUp4Brexit &bull Channel 5 News)Prime Minister Theresa May's Chequers proposal would see Britain maintain close commercial ties with the EU through a free trade area managed by a common rulebook.Mrs May&rsquos Brexit proposal has sparked fury among Conservative Party members and let to the resignation of Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.A faction of Brexiteer dissidents, spearheaded by Jacob Rees-Mogg, is working to create an &ldquoalternative view to the Government&rsquos White Paper.Still in the development stages, the policy paper they aim to publish is understood to follow a Canadian-style free trade agreement, but only if the EU compromises on demands over the Irish border.

story: Brexit news: Leading law firm believes EU27 will maintain City of London access in no-deal Brexit (Image: )After careful analysis, European law firm Fieldfisher believes the UK&rsquos no-deal planning for financial services will enable EU firms to operate in the country without an agreement with Brussels.Fieldfisher believe any suggestions that EU firms won't enjoy access to British markets for financial services are unfound.Azad Ali, a financial services regulatory partner at the firm, claims the &ldquoaccommodating nature of the UK regulatory regime with regard to overseas firms goes a long way to mitigating the cliff-edge impact of a no-deal for European businesses.He said: &ldquoIt is clear that the Government is making ever effort to ensure that European financial services firms can continue conducting business as usual in the UK after Brexit.&ldquoThe temporary licensing regimes are helpful, but nonetheless introduce additional regulatory friction and are, by nature, transitional.&ldquoMany EU27 firms will not have to rely on the temporary permissions regime in the first place, if they can instead tailor their operations to rely on one of the exclusions from UK financial regulation, such as the overseas person exclusion.&ldquoThe relatively accommodating nature of the UK regulatory regime with regard to overseas firms goes a long way to mitigating the cliff-edge impact of a no-deal for such firms.Fieldfisher&rsquos study finds the temporary permissions regime and overseas person exclusion would provide ample room for European firms to operate within the UK market.The TPR is a transition to full authorisation in the UK, allowing firms to submit an application to full authorisation. Whereas, an OPR permits various activities to be carried out on a cross-border basis in the UK &ndash mainly benefiting broker-dealer and investment banking activity.                'There is NO such thing as NO DEAL' IDS HITS BACK at 'Project Fear'The study reads: &ldquoCombined with other exclusions, and given certain activities may not be seen as being carried out in the UK at all, many firms could find that the scope of UK authorisation they require in a no-deal scenario is significantly narrower than the scope of their current passport, or is not required at all.&ldquoIndeed a significant volume of business currently carried out in the UK by EU27 firms under the passport can be carried out without falling within the scope of UK authorisation.Theresa May&rsquos Government have ramped up their no-deal preparations and are ready to release at least 80 technical notes designed to help in the event of a hard orce.The Prime Minister has already made a generous offer to EU citizens residing in Britain, giving them the &ldquoright to remain in event of a no-deal Brexit, according to leaked documents.In the wake of Brexit, we look at the 28 member states that are in the European Union.                    Getty1 of 29Countries that are in the European Union The Cabinet papers show ministers are preparing to take the &ldquomoral high ground by unilaterally granting 3.8 million EU nationals in the UK the right to stay.It states: &ldquoThe Home Office plans to make an offer to existing EU residents that they can remain in the UK in a &lsquono-deal&rsquo scenario, in effect unilaterally implementing the immigration element of the citizens&rsquo rights agreement agreed with the EU in December 2017.&ldquoThe proposal is to make the offer irrespective of whether the EU reciprocates. Any package would need resolution for the reciprocal elements of the December 2017 deal.&ldquoMaking an offer is not only important to provide certainty publicly, but will enable the UK government to take the moral high ground.&ldquoA number of other plans are also dependent on the government&rsquos position on this issue, relying heavily on the availability of existing labour in a &lsquono deal&rsquo scenario.

story: Those in the North of the UK will see wetter weather throughout the week, but the South of England will see the warmer temperatures and muggy weather continuing until mid-week.But it&rsquos good news for many as the BBC&rsquos Alina Jenkins promises a &ldquodry bank holiday weekend for most as a weather front pushing down across the UK clears at the end of this week.Ms Jenkins, filling in this morning for BBC weather regular Carol Kirkwood, told viewers:&ldquoWe&rsquore going to start the week with a lot of cloud, and for many still this very humid feel. story: Hajj 2018 in pictures: Incredible images show Mecca pilgrimage (Image: EPA)Muslims around the world will celebrate Eid al-Adha this week.Eid al-Adha, also known as Festival of Sacrifice, is different from Eid al-Fitr which is celebrated earlier in the year at the end of Ramadan.The Festival of Sacrifice honours Ibrahim&rsquos willingness to sacrifice his own son at the request of God.Eid al-Adha, which takes place between the 10th and 13th of the last Islamic month, follows Hajj which began yesterday.                Hajj 2018: When does Hajj start? Who performs Hajj and where is pil...During Hajj, many Muslims make a pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia during a five day period.The Islamic pilgrimage must be carried out at least once in a lifetime by all adult Muslims who are physically able.It occurs between the 8th and 12th day of the last month of the Islamic calendar, the Dhu al-Hijjah which is based on lunar events.Several rituals are performed at the arrival of the Kaaba, the cube-shaped building at the centre of the mosque.Pilgrims must circle the building counter-clockwise seven times.Pilgrims must circle the Kaaba counter-clockwise seven times (Image: EPA)In 2013, over a million people reportedly made the journey to Saudi Abrabia to perform the Hajj.See the best pictures of Hajj 2018 and Eid Al-Adha.Muslim Hajj pilgrims touch the Kaaba stone  (Image: Getty)An aerial view shows some of the cars used by pilgrims before they leave from Mina (Image: EPA)Hajj pilgrims pray in the Mount Arafat near Mecca (Image: EPA)Around 2.5 million Muslims are expected to attend this year's Hajj pilgrimage (Image: EPA)An aerial view of the Mount Arafat, where worshippers gather during the Hajj pilgrimage (Image: EPA)Pilgrims pray during the Hajj pilgrimage on Mount Arafat, Saudi Arabia (Image: EPA)A Muslim pilgrim prays while gathering with others atop Mount Arafat (Image: Getty)Mount Arafat is southeast of the Saudi holy city of Mecca (Image: Getty)Worshippers gather at Mount Arafat (Image: EPA)Muslim pilgrims pray during the Hajj pilgrimage at Mount Arafat near Mecca (Image: EPA)Mount Arafat is also known as Jabal al-Rahma (Mount of Mercy) (Image: Getty)Muslin pilgrims pictured one day prior to Eid al-Adha (Image: EPA)The Feast of the Sacrifice is the second of two religious holidays celebrated by Muslims (Image: Getty)Breeders are pictured with animals at a livestock market ahead of Eid al-Adha in Islamabad, Pakistan (Image: Getty)

title: Lombok Indonesia earthquake huge quake
story: Woman carries her child past collapsed homes in Indonesia (Image: AFPGetty Images)Injured patients and their family members are forced to stay at crammed makeshift hospital wards exposed to the elements, while others are forced to take shelter in tents.Homes and buildings have been reduced to rubble with huge gaping cracks rippling through the roads of Mataram, Lombok's main city.One image shows a woman covered in blood from a head injury, with Indonesian National Search and Rescue Agency (BASARNAS) giving her treatment under pitch black skies as she sits in the street.And another heart wrenching snap shows a woman carrying her child through the leftover wreckage as whole houses are reduced to rubble and debris.Woman takes shelter under a tent in Indonesia (Image: AFPGetty Images)                Lombok earthquake death toll: How many people have died in latest t...                Lombok EARTHQUAKE: 10 people KILLED as landslides STRIKE near Bali ...Military personnel arrived in helicopters in a bid to help to the relief effort, distributing supplies to the many residents left without roofs over their heads.Lombok was rocked by strong tremors on Sunday which were felt as far away as Bali - the latest in a series of earthquakes that killed hundreds and forced thousands to flee their homes in recent weeks.Nearly 500 people have died in quakes and aftershocks since July 29 across the northern coast of the island, which lies just east of Indonesia's top tourist destination, Bali.Sutopo Purwo Nugroho, a spokesman at the national disaster mitigation agency, said on Monday relief and reconstruction efforts had been intensified.The rebuilding of public facilities like hospitals and schools is being speeded up, he said.Man jumps over a crack in the ground in Mataram (Image: AFPGetty Images)                Lombok earthquake: Red Cross SCRAMBLE to evacuate residentsDevastation in Lombok after huge earthquake (Image: AFPGetty Images)He said more than 100 aftershocks had been recorded since Sunday night's magnitude 6.9 quake, which sent panicked residents into the streets and cut power and communication lines across the island.Aftershocks ranging between magnitude 4 and 5 were continuing on Monday morning and access to some areas had been cut off by landslides triggered by the tremors, according to officials in Mataram, Lombok's main city.Sunday's quake came exactly a fortnight after another 6.9 magnitude earthquake which killed around 460 people and prompted massive search, rescue and relief efforts.Authorities estimate that the August 5 earthquake caused 5 trillion rupiah ($342 million) of damage on Lombok.Hundreds of thousands of residents have been left homeless and are camped out in open fields, refusing to shelter indoors due to continuing tremors.Aid organisations like Save The Children said they were ready to scale up their humanitarian response.The population feels like it's had the rug pulled from under them with this new quake, said Caroline Haga, humanitarian &amp emergency communications specialist with the Red Cross.

title: we are finally showing brussels we can go it alone after brexit and not before time
story: The publication of “technical notices” outlining how life will continue more or less as normal if the EU refuses to do a deal with Britain for petty political reasons is a crucial boost to our negotiating hand.Compare this grown-up approach to what Brussels and some European leaders have been up to recently.The EU has accused MI6 of bugging our Brexit talks. And our “ally” across the Irish Sea, the rent-a-quote Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, is threatening to ground our planes the day we leave.The silly season is coming to an end but it seems only Britain is getting serious.There is still much to do if, as we suspect, Brussels has no interest in negotiating in good faith. They are so terrified by the collapse of their project, thanks to unrest everywhere from Italy to Poland, that they’re willing to make themselves poorer as a result.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab must get his department moving quicker and force other parts of government to speed up their preparation.But we are finally showing we can go it alone. Not before time.AMAZON appear to be launching another front in their all-out war to take over just about every bit of our lives, with plans for a comparison site.This doesn’t fill us with excitement. After all, in recent days we’ve learnt that Brits are being charged over the odds for their Prime subscriptions, a service which itself has been shown not to deliver on its “next day” promises.We’ve no problem with competition or businesses doing well. Good companies with good profits create good jobs.But they must play by the rules, especially when other firms — such as high street retailers — are struggling.It is still staggering to us that Amazon’s UK tax bill FELL last year despite it almost tripling its profits.The Chancellor must close the costly loopholes that tech giants continue to exploit.WE’RE saying a little prayer for the Queen of Soul.Aretha Franklin redefined the music landscape, her songs influencing everybody from Luther Vandross to Adele.But she also raised huge amounts of money for the civil rights struggle in the US, doing it not for publicity but because she believed in it.Her extraordinary take on Otis Redding’s Respect became an anthem not just for African Americans but for feminists the world over.Rest in peace.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madonna best at being madge
story: She might have had a bit of assistance to retain such a fresh-faced youthfulness, but the body is all her own work.Through hours of  gym graft and sheer willpower she’s even more bendy now than when she first burst on to the scene back in 1984 warbling Holiday in a Minnie Mouse falsetto.Madonna is the biggest-selling female artist ever, shifting 300million albums and is worth around 454million quid.She’s achieved success on her own terms and been a trailblazer for every other successful female act following in her wake. There would be no Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus or arguably Lady Gaga without Madonna.She might not be the best singer or dancer in the world, but she’s certainly the best at just being Madonna.You simply can’t imagine anyone ever telling her what to do. She’d laugh in their face.Madonna had always known how to grab attention, whether it’s publishing a book stuffed full of naked photos of herself, faking self-pleasure on stage, or kissing Britney Spears.And only Madonna could have bounced back from almost being strangled by her bright red Armani cape when she took a tumble and fell on her backside during the Brit Awards three years ago.She merely dusted herself down and carried on regardless, but I bet whoever was in charge of her wardrobe that night would have been given the b******ing of their life.Madonna is always in charge, professionally and personally. Even during her brief fling with aging lothario Warren Beatty, he was very much a bit player in the Madonna Show.That must have badly bruised the ego of a man who had always had the upper-hand in his relationships until then.It has to be said her love life hasn’t been anywhere near as successful as her career.There was a brief, destructive marriage to American actor Sean Penn in the Eighties and in 2000 she married Guy Ritchie, but the couple divorced eight years later.Since then she has dated a string of handsome and often young men, but they usually seemed to have the whiff of a photo opportunity about them rather than anything long term.She chews them up, spits them out and moves on to the next one.Madonna seems happiest as a single mum.She has uprooted the family to Lisbon, in Portugal,  because her adopted son David wants to play professional football.With her vast wealth she could easily have bought him a team such as LA Galaxy but she has always had a Calvinistic work ethic that she has tried to pass on to her kids.She has also made up with son Rocco Ritchie after a bitter custody battle and appears to be in a very good place.In an era where most young female vocalists all sound the same — bored, whiny and more than a wee bit yodelly — we really do need a one-off like Madonna.I hope she had a fabulous birthday on Thursday in Marrakech, Morocco, and danced until dawn to all of her greatest hits.Happy 60th birthday, ma’am, and I’ve no doubt you will still be in your fishnets and basques when you get that 100-year birthday message.Just when the royals and their advisers thought the whole fiasco between Meghan Markle and her dad had gone quiet, there comes a bizarre twist.Meghan’s rent-a-gob half-sister Samantha, who seethes with rage and jealousy, has announced that Thomas Markle is bringing out his own clothing range.This led to speculation as to what the brand might be called.  “Markle &amp Spencer” or “Primarkles”  (thank you, Alan Carr). But joking aside, surely this can’t be a serious  concept.Apart from being a crass, money-grabbing exercise cashing in on a quasi-royal connection, who on earth would buy garments from a pensioner who dresses like a hobo?I’ve had a great deal of sympathy for Thomas  in the past. He was treated poorly in the build-up to the  Royal Wedding, when his daughter married Prince Harry.He should have been embraced by his new family and given guidance on how to deal with the  media attention.Instead he was cast adrift. The result? Those stupid paparazzi set-up photos and a series of interviews that painted Meghan in a poor light.Every time her dad talks on TV or to newspapers and magazines, her popularity is dented.The two of them obviously have a fraught relationship. It turns out Thomas didn’t attend Meghan’s first wedding in 2011 either.Thomas increasingly comes across as bitter, angry and dislikable.To gain media attention he keeps making more and more outrageous accusations.My advice would be to stop listening to his bitchy daughter Samantha and maintain a dignified silence.All thoughts of profiteering through a clothing range or any commercial activity must be abandoned forthwith.That just might mean there could be some  sort of reconciliation in the future.Otherwise he will lose his daughter forever.ONE of the week’s most astonishing stories involved a young US woman who has been given her life back with a groundbreaking face transplant.Three years ago, Katie Stubblefield, from Mississippi in the US, tried to take her own life and shot herself in the face with a hunting rifle. She was just 18.Doctors saved her life but she was left with a mass of scar tissue instead of a face.Katie, the youngest person ever to receive a face transplant, endured more than 30 hours of surgery.Of course, the operation requires a donor – and in this case it is  a very sad story.Katie received the face  of a mum who died of a drug overdose.She was a registered organ donor and her grandmother bravely approved the donation.That decision can’t have been easy and we should always salute those who are donors, and the loved ones who give their consent.Katie won’t look like anything like her donor because the “face” is moulded on to her new bone structure.She continues to heal and  make progress, but this kind of surgery is still in its infancy.She will always look “different” but she has a second chance of life and now wants to help others in anguish and with suicidal thoughts.It’s an incredible story of despair that turned to  hope.  The skill and dedication of the team of surgeons and medics that helped her is awe-inspiring.I’m always surprised to learn that Caroline Flack is 38 years old.The presenter looks a  lot younger – and at the moment she is acting like a lovesick teenager going through the agony and ecstasy of her first serious crush.Her off/on romance with red carpet fever victim Andrew Brady is becoming laughable.This week the couple apparently had yet another spat in a London ­restaurant.If these two are to have any chance of staying together long term, they need to get out of the public eye and spend some quiet time alone.I’m sure Caroline knows of a certain Love Island that isn’t being used right now. That would do very well.The ending of the second series of The Handmaid’s Tale had me shouting in despair at my TV.I don’t want to give away too many spoilers but this cliffhanger will break your heart.It also, however, sets up season three for long overdue revenge.As always, astonishing performances from Elisabeth Moss as  June/Ofglen and Yvonne Strahovski as Serena Joy.They will soon fight it out for real when the TV actress awards are up for grabs.I’ve lost track of the amount of slippers our border terrier puppy Angus has chewed up, but this week he surpassed himself by getting his paws on his Pet Passport and virtually destroying it when we were in Spain.Luckily a  local vet issued him with a Spanish version and he now boasts dual nationality.He’s suddenly developed a liking for an afternoon siesta, but at least we were able to get him back into the UK – although who knows what will happen to him after Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public realised leopard corbyn spots
story: If Corbyn wishes to deny the obvious that is his prerogative the notion you should be prepared to swallow any and every piece of whitewashing nonsense peddled by his fans is quite a different matter.“I was present” when the wreath was laid “but I don’t think I was involved in it” is, I suppose, a step forward from the Labour party’s previous suggestion that “The Munich widows are being misled. Jeremy did not honour those responsible for the Munich killings”.Holding a wreath should not be reckoned to be any kind of endorsement of the wreath we know Jeremy deplores this kind of thing and, indeed, all other forms of wreath.Hark, though, at how quickly the approved line may shift. What was a “smear” yesterday is a forgotten truth today, airbrushed from history because, well, that’s the way these people do these things.The new line is Jeremy wants to see “a fitting memorial to everyone who died in every terrorist incident everywhere”.I dare say he’ll be visiting Enniskillen soon. Of course.And yet, in one sense there really isn’t very much to look at. Or, rather, very little that is new. This is who Corbyn is and who he has always been.He has never bothered hiding this, leaving one to assume he only does so now because there is some small, nagging part of his brain which accepts it might be sensible to do so, since failing to hide it might prove politically inconvenient.Even so, he cannot change. Anyone who has been at university will recognise Corbyn and all his fellow travellers.These were the people — some of them clever but not many of them intelligent — who fouled student politics for everyone else.The chiselling parsers and pedants and revolutionaries whose appetite for procedural minutiae bored everyone else into submission.And usually that would be that. They would, most of them, grow up eventually. But not St Jeremy and not his devotional disciples, either.They are greyer now but as instantly recognisable as they always were: Experts in room-clearing.They ought, by rights, to be confined to dingy rooms above down-at-heel pubs, where they could cut and paste their thuddingly dreary newsletters. Instead, mystifyingly, they have been given control of one of Britain’s great political parties.How much will this summer of anti-Semitism really cut through with the average voter? Less than you might think, I suspect.In the first place — and this may be a good thing — Twitter remains a niche platform and political Twitter a niche even there.Secondly, the public have already made up their minds about Corbyn and they think he’s a dud.Each month YouGov asks whether Jeremy Corbyn or Theresa May seems the best available Prime Minister and each month Corbyn trails.Sometimes he is also beaten by “Don’t know”. That’s Corbyn: He can come third in a two-horse race.But, they splutter, look at what a kind and gentle and decent man he is. Why can’t other people see that he’s a valiant activist for peace?Possibly because, for a decent fellow, he spends a startling amount of time with thoroughly indecent people.He keeps falling in with the wrong crowd while never being a member of the wrong crowd himself. There is no need here to document the long list of unsavoury people with whom Corbyn has been happy to associate himself because, really, what is now the point? He is who he is and we know who he is.In Corbyn’s world every-thing has a single, simple explanation. Colonialism is the root cause of all root causes.That insight — if we can call it that — dictated his views on Ireland just as it dictates his views on the Middle East, Cuba, Venezuela and everywhere else.From there it is but a short leap to the kind of deluded wishful thinking that animates what passes for his thinking. Once you have assumed that Northern Ireland should not exist, you absolve yourself of any and all need to think about what should happen next.You may ignore the inconvenient, and stubborn, reality that Northern Ireland — like, well, Israel — does exist and is not going to disappear.Practical politics means wrestling with things as they are, not as you think they should have been decades previously.But if you start with the theory, you may avoid practical reality. If this leaves you with nothing — precisely nothing — useful to say then so be it. You will at least remain pure in heart.If this means you are no kind of “peace campaigner” at all, that’s fine too, because you will be shielded by your own impenetrable sanctimony.As poses go, this is an awfully comfortable one but it’s not serious politics.Perhaps Corbyn really is just unlucky. But it seems more probable that he’s not. And that, far from being the decent man of legend he’s actually thoroughly indecent.The only possible alternative is that he’s thunderously, crushingly, toe-curlingly thick.On balance, however, it seems more probable that he is, in fact, both.Enough of this. Enough, already.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british voters give brexit verdict
story: Nearly half of Brits think we should leave the EU on March 29 with or without a deal, a Sun on Sunday poll reveals.They are sick of Brussels bullying and resistant MPs stalling — and simply want ministers to deliver.The mood of the nation is hardening after two years of bitter rows and fruitless negotiations since the historic referendum result.An overwhelming 62 per cent say they have not changed their minds. Those who have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Many people are deeply sceptical about the tedious stumbling blocks that have bogged down the process.Almost half — 48 per cent — think the political classes are deliberately making heavy weather of Brexit in the hope it will convince the public to change their minds.Six in ten believe the EU is out to punish the UK by refusing to compromise in talks on trade and free movement, our Deltapoll survey says.But the vast majority are convinced a departure deal will be hammered out in the end, even if it takes longer than expected.Former Cabinet minister Priti Patel last night said: “The Sun on Sunday’s poll shows that the British people ultimately believe we can build a stronger future for our country outside the EU.Nearly half of adults believe the weather goes in cycles and that heatwaves come around from time to time.Barely a third of voters believe the human race is responsible and that we will have more extreme temperatures unless we act soon.Our poll found that a majority of 18 to 24-year-olds blame global warming for the hottest British summer since 1976.But in every other age group, most people think it has little or nothing to do with climate change.Six in ten over-55s believe it was “just another hot summer”.“It is clear that most people are sick to the back teeth of being ­bullied by the EU and listening to politicians at home erecting all kinds of obstacles to prevent them honouring the referendum result.“The Government should sit up and heed the results of this poll. That means being tougher in negotiations with Brussels and doing what the nation voted for — to get Britain out of the EU.”Most people — 55 per cent — are against a second in-out referendum, according to our poll.Forty per cent think we should just leave in 222 days’ time as planned with or without a deal.Fifteen per cent want a vote on the final deal, but not a re-run on whether or not Britain leaves the EU.Overall, only 13 per cent have changed their minds on Brexit since the referendum on June 23, 2016. Most of those were once Remainers. Fifteen per cent of them admit to having shifted their view — equivalent to 2.4 million people.That compares with just 11 per cent of Brexit backers, 1.9 million, who have had a rethink.Ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said the poll had “nailed the lie” that many people regret voting Leave.Deltapoll director Martin Boon said the findings show most people are taking a tougher stance on Brexit.He added: “Half the public believe themselves to be under siege from the political classes trying to change their minds.“But the message they are sending back is that they haven’t changed their minds and the likelihood is they won’t.”Voters are evenly divided on whether there will be a hard border after Brexit. Twenty-two per cent say there will, 21 per cent say otherwise.There is also a split over whether leaving the EU will prove a historic mistake. Forty-four per cent think it will, 30 per cent believe it will not. One statement united 59 per cent of voters — “I’m really bored by Brexit.”Separately, our poll found that most people think former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson was right to raise the difficult and sensitive issue of women wearing burkas. Two-thirds believe he was right to start a debate about the Muslim veil.But some say he should say sorry because he went “over the top” by comparing wearers to “bank robbers” or “letterboxes”. Half of Tory supporters and 36 per cent of all voters believe his remarks were right and he has nothing to apologise for.A further 28 per cent say he went a little too far with his language and should admit it.He gets no support from 23 per cent, who say his remarks were offensive and he should say sorry.Deltapoll interviewed an online sample of 1,904 adults aged 18+ from August 14 to 16. Results have been weighted to the profile of all GB adults.The Labour leader has defied the odds after damaging revelations about the friends he keeps.Half of voters believe Labour has a problem with anti-Semitism. More than a third say Mr Corbyn is part of that problem.But a Sun on Sunday Deltapoll has Labour three points ahead of the Tories.If there were an election tomorrow, Labour would be 31 seats short of a majority but with enough MPs to form a government with Scottish Nationalist support.Tory backing has been sapped as traditional supporters switch to Ukip in protest over the PM’s weak handling of Brexit.There is little to celebrate for any of the party leaders who all get negative popularity ratings.Mr Corbyn scores minus 35, while Theresa May is on minus 26 — only two points better than floundering Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable.Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum.Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear.We didn’t and they’re not.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: young women getting 99 botox
story: After all, in the era of Love Island and social media, we’re all potential celebrities now. Even those of us who will never hit the big time have an Instagram audience waiting to “like” our every selfie.So this is just the logical next step towards making cosmetic surgery available to the masses, rather than the few.Some have argued that Superdrug Botox is actually a good thing, because it bridges the gap between the elite Harley Street options — where you pay several hundred pounds for an appointment with an “aesthetic doctor” — and the more backstreet treatments carried out by hairdressers with just a few hours of training.I disagree. Being able to buy a syringe or two of Botox when you are out shopping for your hairspray legitimises — and normalises — the act of injecting poison in your skin in the name of beauty.Being able to buy Botox over the counter, so to speak, makes it seem like no big deal — just another tick in the “maintenance” box, and as reasonable as tinting your lashes or getting your ears pierced.And that is the problem. All decisions we make about our appearance boil down to personal choice. And if it makes someone feel better to tinker cosmetically or surgically with their natural looks, that’s their choice. No one should judge them for it.But there is a wider problem.Increasingly, women think that whatever they look like naturally isn’t good enough. More and more, the “solution” is invasive cosmetic enhancement.A mainstream shop making Botox available for less than 100 quid is surely only going to add to the pressure some women feel to change their appearance using more than just make-up.Superdrug presents itself as responsible because it will refuse to treat under-25s, when other clinics will.That is shocking — not so much that some clinics WILL treat under-25s but that anyone so young could think they need Botox.You can’t blame Superdrug for this epidemic. It is simple supply and demand.The question is: Why the growing desire among women to look frozen?It’s not like you can get away with saying you’ve not had it when you have, because it’s so obvious.I’ve got a friend whose husband jokes that she needs to hold up little signs saying “happy” or “angry” when she feels an emotion, since her face is so paralysed by botulism.While I’m a big believer in your body, your choice, I’m also a believer in scratching the right itch.The truth is if you feel good about yourself, you look good. If you feel bad and lack confidence, nothing, no amount of Botox or fillers, will ever change that.Just look at Meg from Love Island, above, who, even after an estimated £40,000 worth of plastic surgery, is still massively insecure.Because it’s not what’s on the outside that counts, it’s what’s on the inside.The problem is our society tends to give far too much weight to the outside. That is especially the case for women, but increasingly for men, too.I realise all of this is easy to say, harder to act on. I’m as susceptible as the next person to comparing myself with ­others more beautiful — and possibly more airbrushed — and finding myself lacking.I’m just glad that, when that happens, I know the thing that will make me feel better is far more likely to be self-acceptance than Botox.After all, if you tighten a prune you don’t get a grape — you just get a tight prune!So the really big question is, how to achieve self-acceptance when we are surrounded by all these images of perfection?Well, we are all on our own journey with that one but I’ve got some suggestions which might help.The first is to focus on what you have, rather than what you don’t. And the second is to never, ever compare yourself to anyone else.Forget Botox, you can have that advice for free.You’re welcome.We all enjoyed cheering on the Three Lions players that would quickly become our heroes during the World Cup in Russia this summer.Sadly, those heady days are over and we were reminded of the seamier side of sport this week with the arrest of England rugby union ace Danny Cipriani.His embarrassing brawl outside a Jersey nightclub came hot on the heels of England cricket’s Ben Stokes’ trial over his clash with two men during a night out.Stokes was cleared, but what links these sorry sagas is our drinking culture, which dictates that consuming excessive amounts of alcohol is a normal way of letting off steam.Sportsmen are supposed to be role models, as they influence young people and need to keep themselves in good physical shape.But as long as we think it is OK to binge and push our bodies to the limits rather than sip a few drinks, then violence, injuries and stupid mistakes will continue to be a regular feature of our nights out.And if you are an England sports star, then public shame is just one of the tragic consequences – along with the end of your career – that you might have to face.Why should anyone be surprised at the news that sexual harassment in the police force is rife?Let’s face it, it happens everywhere. So why should the police be any exception?I thought they might hold themselves to higher standards. But no.A new survey reveals that dirty jokes, inappropriate touching, leering and being pressured to have sex are daily issues for many police staff.In a survey of almost 1,800 police staff in England, Wales and Scotland, half had heard sexualised jokes and one in five had received a sexually explicit email or text from a colleague.Shockingly, one in five had also been touched in a way that made them feel uncomfortable.Our head of police at West Ham is a woman.She is smart, tough, brave and would never put up with this type of behaviour.Part of the problem is that many women accept these actions as “normal” and don’t even know how to object. We must learn to stop putting up with it.But it is much more important that men learn what is OK and what is not.End of.Jacinda Ardern – the Prime Minister of New Zealand, who has continued to work since becoming a mother in June – was criticised this week for “using her baby as a prop” after she was seen breastfeeding her daughter at a public meeting.I guess whoever coined that phrase has never had the experience of looking after a baby who needs to be fed – right NOW.Nor will they have dealt with the very loud consequences of that failing to happen.Instead, what about congratulating Jacinda on doing such a great job of being a working mum?We said farewell to two legends last week, let’s remember them with this wonderful meme....So interesting that the day after A-level results arrived, more than 26,000 university places were still available.An Ipsos Mori poll found that while most students still think university is “important”, that is down from 86 per cent five years ago to 75 per cent now.Since a degree is expensive – and no guarantee of a job – you can see why people are questioning the validity of one.However, there is no viable alternative.There are just 10,000 degree-level apprenticeships available, compared with 300,000 university places, according to Sir Peter Lampl, of the Sutton Trust.We need to think how we prepare young people for work and we need more technical qualifications at degree level that offer the chance of a bright future.GOT a story? title: remoaners dream second referendum codswallop
story: Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum. Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave. Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear. We didn’t and they’re not.DEFENCE Secretary Gavin Williamson was right to stand up to France after they tried to bill us £2million for helping them stamp out a jihadi insurrection in Mali.Mr Williamson reportedly threatened to ground our choppers in retaliation. Good.The French also reneged on a deal to support a Nato mission in Estonia.As their closest military ally in Europe, we deserve better.Otherwise, next time, Mr Williamson will be entitled to say: “Zut alors! No more!”IT is scandalous that cops in the capital are reliant on weapon-detecting equipment donated by the public.Knife crime is the most deadly threat our youngsters face on the streets today.This week two men were killed and four teenagers stabbed in separate incidents.How can we expect cops to stamp out this deadly crimewave if they are reliant on public donations?The Government needs to properly start tackling this crisis. Lives depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
