title: 5 utterly appalling hmp birmingham
story: News5 utterly appalling HMP Birmingham facts that reveal the 'squalor and violence' at G4S-run jailRats and cockroaches, blood and excrement, and fearful staff locking themselves away in their offices - here are the worst findings at HMP BirminghamShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter10:41, 20 AUG 2018Updated12:12, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailToday, years of Tory privatisation and austerity are the dock. Private prison giant G4S has been stripped of its contract to run squalid HMP Birmingham after one of the most shocking inspections ever seen. Rats and cockroaches ran free in the jail as blood, vomit and excrement lay unattended and fearful staff locked themselves away in their offices. Chief Inspector Peter Clarke called for an independent inquiry - declaring there had been a dramatic deterioration after the worst UK jail riot for 20 years in 2016. Mr Clarke blamed austerity after Tory ministers slashed 7,000 officers - only to rehire 2,500 amid safety fears - and said the contract between government and G4S has failed. Yet arrogant prisons minister Rory Stewart claimed there were many reasons for the explosion in violence.  From today the Ministry of Justice will run HMP Birmingham for at least six months, and longer if conditions do not improve. Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon said: This should be a nail in the coffin for the flawed idea of prison privatisation. So as the political debate rages, what did the report actually say? We've looked at some of the most appalling findings. 1. 'Fearful' prison staff lock THEMSELVES away  Fearful prison officers are frequently hospitalised and lock themselves away in their offices in the clearly unsafe jail. Many staff were anxious and indeed fearful as they went about their duties, the chief inspector said. Wings were poorly supervised and prisoners routinely disregarded rules, even to the extent of open drug use. On more than one occasion we found groups of staff who had locked themselves in their own offices. We were told this was to prevent them, when busy, from being distracted by prisoners – an explanation that was neither plausible nor acceptable. 2. Urine and excrement are flung through cell doors  Inspectors found some prisoners were refusing to emerge from their cells for 24 hours a day due to fear of violence. Even while they were inside, other inmates squirted urine or threw excrement through broken observation panels in their doors. One distressed inmate said repeatedly they stole my mattress three days after the theft. Another clearly troubled man suffered appalling bullying when inmates adorned his door with the slogan Say No to BO and soaked him with a fire hose. Three inmates have killed themselves in the last 18 months and three more died from suspected 'new psychiatric substances' like Spice. Although probes are ongoing, there are significant concerns about the standards of care for those self-harming.  Communal areas in most wings were filthy, the report said. There were widespread problems with insects, including cockroaches, as well as rats and other vermin. We saw evidence of bodily fluids left unattended, including blood and vomit. I saw a shower area where there was bloodstained clothing and a pool of blood that had apparently been there for two days, next to numerous rat droppings.  Many cells were cramped, poorly equipped and had damaged flooring or plasterwork. Most toilets were poorly screened, many were leaking and we saw cells with exposed electrics. Inspectors said virtually every window was broken or missing in the older part of the Victorian jail and vulnerable inmates were placed in squalid cells. By mid-August, work to replace windows still hadn't begun. Within a matter of weeks many prisoners will be forced to use blankets, towels or clothing to keep the cold out, the chief inspector wrote. 4. The cannabis fumes are so strong the inspector felt it  For the first time in his career, Mr Clarke said the blatant cannabis fumes were so strong he could feel the effects of the drug. One in SEVEN inmates had developed a drug habit - since arriving at the jail. We saw many prisoners under the influence of drugs and the smell of cannabis and other burning substances pervaded many parts of the prison, Mr Clarke said. I have inspected many prisons where drugs are a problem, but nowhere else have I felt physically affected by the drugs in the atmosphere – an atmosphere in which it is clearly unsafe for prisoners and staff to live and work. He added: When inspectors at one point raised the fact that drugs were clearly being smoked on a wing, the response from staff was to shrug. 5. An arsonist torched nine cars DURING the inspection week  Today's report paints a picture of a jail where inmates, not staff, were in control. Many violent inmates did not even face sanctions leaving them free to commit a reign of terror with near impunity, the inspectors said. That included an arson attack on a supposedly secure car park - destroying nine staff vehicles in the same week inspectors were there. We observed a prison where control was tenuous, Mr Clarke said. Accounting for prisoners was poor, with wing staff often not knowing where their prisoners were at any given time. In at least one case, a prisoner who had been removed from a wing where he had been intimidating others managed, inexplicably, to find his way back to the same wing. Yet G4S looks free to win more contracts

title: chip shop worker 20 reveals
story: NewsChip shop worker, 20, reveals creepy messages of stalker who bombarded her with up to '50 texts A DAY'Charlotte Kendall's suspicions were first aroused when Terry Waymark, 36, introduced himself as a police officer and wouldn't stop talking to herShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByOlive Loveridge-GreeneAmber Hicks12:44, 20 AUG 2018NewsCharlotte met Terry Waymark when she served him a portion of chips (Image: SWNS)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA chip shop worker has revealed her fear after a creepy stalker claiming to be a police officer began bombarding her with up to '50 texts a day'. The dozens of messages left Charlotte Kendall so terrified she didn't want to leave her house for three weeks - and when she did, her mum escorted her. The 20-year-old first met Terry Waymark, 36, when she served him a &pound2 portion of chips during an evening shift at work. But after taking a business card off the counter for her animal portrait company, he began to relentlessly text, call and email her. Waymark asked her on dates, called her late at night and constantly asked to meet up with her – threatening he would return to her workplace if they didn’t.  However, Charlotte eventually went to police when he texted her to say he knew she had been on holiday to Cornwall for four days. Just one day later, police pounced on menace Waymark and he was found guilty of stalking involving serious alarm or distress. He was jailed for four years and given an indefinite restraining order at Portsmouth Crown Court. Now with her stalker - also a convicted arsonist - behind bars, Charlotte, from Portsmouth, hopes her story will encourage other victims not to suffer in silence. The brave young woman, who is due to study veterinary nursing at university soon, said: It was constant. It didn’t seem to matter if I replied or not as the texts just kept on coming. “He was constantly asking if he could phone me but I made it clear we could discuss everything over the email and texts. “But then he asked whether I had kids and if I was single.  “I instantly sent a text back and asking why my current relationship status would affect the portrait. “Then he was asking if he could take me out sometime as ‘he knew a lot about me’. “Then he mentioned he would drop off an iPhone 6 at my work so we could talk. “I was freaked out. “Then he asked if I worked in the chip shop and if I had gone away to Cornwall and that’s when the penny dropped. “I realised Terry was the customer who mentioned he was a police officer. “I’m just glad we’re all safe and he’s locked up. If I hadn’t gone to the police when I did who knows how far he would have gone? “I still work in the chip shop as I’m putting money aside for university.  “But I’m more reserved with customers now. I just keep it to the basic ‘hello’ and ‘thank you’ as I don’t want to go through that again. “But hopefully what I’ve been through will encourage others to report potential stalkers. Charlotte first met Waymark while working an evening shift at her local chippie in Leigh Park, Hampshire in October last year. Impersonating a local police officer, he lingered around the takeaway asking questions for 30 minutes before politely being asked to leave. She said: “It around 8.30pm on a typical Thursday when Terry walked in asking for a &pound2 portion of chips. “I noticed he was a new face as I’ve worked there four years and know who all regulars are. “He introduced himself as a local police officer which at the time I thought was an odd thing to do.  “I don’t know anyone who goes around shouting about their job willy-nilly. “He didn’t mention his name but kept going on and on about his job. “He was going on about the murder rate and how much of a dangerous area it is. “Then it was a bit more light-hearted and he asked if I lived in the area and how my day was going. “But he was looking at me square in the eye. It was just intense. “Usually customers only wait around if they’re waiting for their fish to be battered but he was just there with his chips going cold.  “My boss had to come over and tell him we were closing to make him leave.” In what was dismissed as an awkward customer encounter, Charlotte turned up to work as usual for the next two weeks. But while talking to a regular about her upcoming trip to Cornwall the shop door swung open only to mark the return of ‘PC Terry’. “I was joking about the amount of pasties and ice creams I’ll eat before a man with a bald head and stubble walked in”, she said. “My initial thought was ‘oh God not him again’.” “I didn’t want to get stuck in another half an hour conversation so I hid round the back and got my boss to serve him. “He seemed to be in and out pretty quick and didn’t bother hanging around. “I managed to dodge him.”  But Charlotte was unaware the creep had managed to swipe one of her business cards with all her contact details. Later that evening she received an email from a potential customer asking for a painting for one of his kids - sealing it off with eight kisses. She said: “I thought it was weird but needed to put money towards my dog’s vet bills. “At the time I just thought ‘a commission is a commission’. “I messaged asking what animal he was after and within seconds I got a reply asking if he could call me. “I had just finished a five hour shift and was exhausted so I just made the excuse that my phone couldn’t take calls. “But that wasn’t working. He just continued to ask if he could phone me.  “At this point I just thought Terry was a pushy customer.” Over the next seven days Charlotte was receiving between 20-50 text messages a day. Charlotte told her mum who encouraged her to phone the police. “As soon as I mentioned his name the police officer said ‘Ah, he’s known to us.’ “The police told me to send one reply telling him not to contact me again. “They then told me if I received a response to come back and they’ll take action.” Despite assurances from the police that she was in safe hands, Charlotte was still fearing her harasser was watching her every move.  Not willing to take any chances, she swapped shifts in a bid to avoid bumping into him. She was also chaperoned by her mum and her pet dog to and from her 20 minute walk to work. Two days after Charlotte received a message from a new number asking her out. Realising who it was, she went straight to the police where they arrested Waynark immediately. He was locked up at Portsmouth Crown Court having been found guilty of stalking involving serious alarm or distress. The defendant had previously been handed a 24 week sentence for harassing an ex-girlfriend after she broke up with him for impersonating a police officer.

title: cruise ship plunge what helped
story: NewsCruise ship plunge passenger's amazing survival - the reasons why Kay Longstaff survived 10 hours in the oceanThe 46-year-old fell from the Norwegian Star 60 miles off the coast of Croatia while en route to Venice but miraculously survivedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter09:09, 20 AUG 2018Updated09:47, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn air hostess who was pulled from the sea 10 hours after she fell from the seventh deck of a cruise ship was helped by yoga , her gender and the time of year. Kay Longstaff, 46, plunged off the 92,000-ton Norwegian Star 60 miles off the Croatian coast as it headed toward Venice on Saturday. She had spent the evening drinking on the vessel which was sailing to Venice from the port of Vargarola in Croatia and fell from the enormous ship, into the Adriatic Sea. The 46-year-old told Croatian media that she had fallen off the back of the ship. CCTV is now being studied to discover how she came to be in the water.  After 10 hours in the ocean she was rescued by a coastguard cutter and Pilatus PC-9 spotter plane. She was found at around 9.30am Sunday morning local time (8.30am UK time) around 1,300 metres from where she vanished and was lifted to safety. Not everyone who falls in the sea would be so lucky with several key factors attributed to her survival.  A rescuer said Kay's yoga fitness and singing helped her survive.  A rescuer said: “She (Kay) said the fact she practices yoga helped her as she was fit. “And she said she was singing to not feel cold in the sea overnight.” The sea is also relatively warm at this time of year. With the hot temperatures the Adriatic Sea is warmer than it would have been at roughly 25C.  If it had been 5C she would not have survived an hour.  But that did not stop Kay developing some signs of hypothermia shortly before being reunited with her family. Being a woman also helped with females having about 10% more body fat than a man so it's easier to float and you spend less energy treading water. Kay was taken to hospital after her ordeal but was discharged a short time later. Croatian Ministry of Maritime Affairs spokesman David Radas said: “Our rescuers were in touch with the Norwegian Star’s crew and by checking CCTV knew the exact moment she fell in the water. “Because they knew the time, they were able to know the exact position of the ship.”  He added to the Daily  that Ms Longstaff was not injured, just exhausted, hypothermic and in shock. When they reached the coast, she felt pretty much recovered. That was also confirmed by the hospital staff after they conducted a preliminary health check.

title: dragons den contestants who snubbed
story: NewsDragons' Den contestants who snubbed offer on the show are now making millionsRevellers are now able to compare prices for events thanks to Steve Pearce and Sam Coley's genius ideaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy RoueClaire Gilbody-Dickerson15:24, 19 AUG 2018Updated07:24, 20 AUG 2018NewsSteave Pearce (left) and Sam Coley's tech start-up is now making millions (Image: Manchester Evening News)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo Dragons' Den contestants who turned down an offer on the BBC show are now making ten times what they originally bid for. Steve Pearce and Sam Coley, both in their mid 20s, are now making millions since founding their tech product TickX, based at Tower 12 in Spinningfields, in the Northern Quarters of Manchester, Manchester Evening News reports. Their business product, which started garnering traction once backed by the Ministry of Sound, is founded on one basic premise: that humans are social animals who love to be entertained. Founded in 2015, the platform brings together events from 75-plus ticket sellers, including Ticketmaster, Headout and Skiddle, allowing users to compare prices and get the best deal for their night out - through the website and app.  The idea came to Pearce while he studied economics at the University of Manchester and found himself desperately sifting through flyers or scrolling websites for the best prices. He said: “There was a lot of conflicting information from ticket vendors and promoters and that’s when I saw the opportunity. “You look at almost every market globally and there is a billion pound aggregator, so if you are booking a flight you would use Skyscanner, hotels maybe Trivago or car rentals would be Rentalcars. We couldn’t believe that there wasn’t already a local or global firm filling that gap in the market so that’s when we decided to join forces on TickX. I bought a sports car instead of going to university The 26-year-old knew he had the business development and sales expertise but was lacking in the product and tech experience - which is where Coley excels. Having grown up on the west coast of Scotland, 25-year-old Coley admits being obsessed with technology and business from a young age.  “It started off with selling toys to my friends and then chewing gum at school to learning about tech and teaching myself to code. “When I was a bit older I set up an online auction site from my bedroom to sell boats called Bid Marine.” Calling it an ‘unbelievable learning curve’ the youngster headed off to Harvard University for work experience before setting up a software development company aged 15. “I started building websites for local businesses and that grew into app development and big scale projects like cloud software.” However, when his youth became a barrier to getting larger projects, the enterprising youngster took an office in the local town and employed his father. Defying expectations he turned down a place at university to focus on the company and fondly remembers buying his first sports car as his friends settled into student life. Starting up TickX Interested by Pearce’s concept for a ticketing comparison site, the pair set out to build a one-stop destination to discover what events were happening, who was selling tickets and at what price. “While Sam was building the platform on evenings and weekends I was going out and bringing on board ticket partners,” says Pearce. Once the product was built and they started getting traction the founders knew it was time to ‘put their foot on the gas.’ “We believe that fortune favours the bold so we wanted to give it a good shot.” This turned out to be very true as they managed to get Ministry of Sound on board after a cold call.  “It was their first ever tech investment and it was a huge stamp of validation for us having one of the biggest independent record labels in the world back TickX,” he added. Coley chips in brightly: “It allowed us to jump that stage of credibility which a lot of small companies struggle with. People instantly took notice and the name had a massive impact.” Now the platform pulls in 125,000 events from more than 75 ticket partners and prioritises them in order of cheapest first. Last year they sold more than &pound4m of tickets and are on track to grow that significantly. In fact, they have set their sights on building it into a billion pound business here in Manchester. Coley explains: “The opportunity there is massive. Globally it is about &pound160bn a year on experience spend - in the UK it’s &pound7bn all in. “It’s a huge market and if we nail it then it is a massive opportunity - that’s why we are excited and why the investors are excited.” Turning down the Dragons Another reason people have been taking notice is their appearance on BBC hit programme Dragons’ Den where the duo audaciously turned down &pound75,000 investment from three dragons. Filmed in May 2016, Pearce recalls: “We never applied to go on to the show. The researchers actually reached out to us after the Manchester Evening News featured TickX in a top start-ups list.” His business partner says: “As we were already trying to raise investment we had the research to hand on what the problem was and how it needed fixing - so we got invited to audition and two weeks later we were pitching to the dragons.” Comparing it to an ‘intense boxing match’ Coley also praised it as ‘an unreal experience’ - although they didn’t expect to be in the pitch for an hour and a half.  “It was pretty surreal because we had both watched the show since we were young and then to find ourselves in the den was crazy.” This intensified as Nick Jenkins, the founder of online greeting card retailer Moonpig, Touker Suleyman and entrepreneur Peter Jones made them offers. However, the pair felt what they were asking for in equity undervalued the business. “We made the brave, or stupid, decision to decline them,” smiles Pearce. “Actually, we realised there are other people out there who can add value to the business and once they were excited about TickX we could find the capital externally.” This risk paid off, literally, as they ended up raising ten times more than what they had asked for in the den. The &pound750,000 funding round was led by 24 Haymarket giving access to a syndicate of industry leaders and high net worth individuals. They also got some investment from Nick Ferguson, the former chairman of BskyB, and tech innovator Stan Boland, who is devising a self driving car. “We were a young team at the time and we just decided to surround ourselves with the best investors, backers and advisors,” remembers Pearce. His business partner agrees emphatically. “We really want to build an A-class team so the first part of that was getting good investors on board including Tim Chambers, the former Ticketmaster executive, who probably had the best industry knowledge you could ask for.” And this desire to pull in the right mix of investors and business leaders has paid off for the team. “The advice for any young entrepreneur starting in businesses is just to really get out there and get meeting people,” explains Pearce. “Also an investor isn’t always what you think an investor is - one of ours is someone I previously worked with. I think it's important to remember that people invest in an idea and the team which will deliver it.” A second round of funding led by venture capitalists BGF Ventures raised &pound3m and will help accelerate their push into Europe. So where is TickX today? The growth has been pretty significant from a few hundred users when they first launched in the UK to more than one million last year. And the only way is up after expanding into new territories, including Ireland and the Netherlands. Not to mention running the ticketing site for NME. So how does it work? TickX is not a ticket selling platform - instead it helps people discover what is happening and to go out more to live events. I find the co-founders are genuinely passionate about this - and albout making sure people don’t get ripped off. The model works as TickX receives a commission from the ticket partner’s booking fee, making them an additional marketing channel to help reach a wider audience and drive up ticket sales. TickX's audience is a very big mix, the paper reports. “We started off focusing on the student market,” says the Manchester graduate. “Then it was young professionals with gigs before we started to see the huge potential in theatre with high order values and commission.” Coley agrees: “Our vision has changed a lot over the last three years. “We started off by focusing on events and now we really see the whole ‘experience market’. “People are looking to spend less money on things and more on going out and experiencing the world. That’s why the market is exploding. “It’s not just about the Instagram story, people don’t want disposable things any more - they want these experiences.” TickX are looking to innovate around this, launching a cinema offering this month and also building on their tech capabilities.

title: edinburgh fringe festivals top 10
story: NewsEdinburgh Fringe Festival's funniest jokes as chosen by comedy fans - here's the top 10Adam Rowe won the 11th annual award for Dave’s Funniest Joke Of The Fringe following in the footsteps of comedy giants Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, Zoe Lyons and Nick HelmShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop08:13, 20 AUG 2018Updated08:26, 20 AUG 2018NewsAdam Rowe won the 11th annual award for Dave’s Funniest Joke Of The Fringe (Image: UKTV Dave/Martina Salvi)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe top ten jokes from this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival have been announced - with a gag about being fired from a Jobcentre topping the list. Adam Rowe won the 11th annual award for Dave’s Funniest Joke Of The Fringe with a one liner from his show Undeniable. The joke won with 41% of a public vote on a shortlist picked by comedy critics, seeing off competition from a host of rising stars. Among them was Olaf Falafel’s: “I took out a loan to pay for an exorcism. If I don’t pay it back, I’m going to get repossessed. Also was Daniel Audritt's: In my last relationship, I hated being treated like a piece of meat. She was a vegan and refused to touch me Winning the award Rowe follows in the footsteps of comedy giants Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, Zoe Lyons and Nick Helm.  Here are the top 10 jokes from the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2018: 1. Working at the JobCentre has to be a tense job - knowing that if you get fired, you still have to come in the next day - Adam Rowe 2. I had a job drilling holes for water - it was well boring - Leo Kearse 3. I took out a loan to pay for an exorcism. If I don't pay it back, I'm going to get repossessed - Olaf Falafel 4. In my last relationship, I hated being treated like a piece of meat. She was a vegan and refused to touch me - Daniel Audritt  5. What do colour blind people do when they are told to eat their greens? - Flo and Joan 6. I've got a new job collecting all the jumpers left in the park at the weekends, but it's not easy. They keep moving the goalposts - Darren Walsh 7. Trump said he'd build a wall but he hasn't even picked up a brick. He's just another middle-aged man failing on a DIY project - Justin Moorhouse 8= I lost a friend after we had an argument about the Tardis. I thought it was a little thing, but it seemed much bigger once we got into it - Adele Cliff 8= Why are they calling it Brexit and not The Great British Break Off? - Alex Edelman 10. I think love is like central heating. You turn it on before guests arrive and pretend it's like this all the time - Laura Lexx  Former bartender Rowe began doing stand-up in 2010 and has previously been crowned Liverpool Comedian of the Year. On winning the award, he said: “I thought my agent was lying. He rang me and told me I couldn’t tell anyone for a week, which has been almost impossible. “I’m massively taken aback by it. I’ve never seen myself as being in the running for things like this. “It’s a massive honour and a genuinely huge surprise.”

title: gatwick displays wiped out technical
story: NewsGatwick Airport staff forced to write flight details by HAND on white board after displays wiped out by technical glitchPassengers scrambled to find out flight information after display boards went down thanks to a 'damaged fibre cable'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop12:39, 20 AUG 2018Updated13:06, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds have faced chaos at Gatwick Airport this morning after flight information boards went down. Passengers scrambled to find out flight information as staff were forced to write down departure details on whiteboards following the technical glitch just after 8am. Travellers crowded around frantically checking which gate they needed to head for as IT experts tried to get the boards back up and running. Gatwick officials said the issues were due to an ongoing problem with Vodafone, which provides IT for the airport. Vodafone said it was down to a damaged fibre cable, which engineers were working hard to fix.   Passengers also claimed the mobile app was not working, as many took to Twitter to ask the airport's customer services team for their gate information.  Footage posted on Twitter shows scores of exasperated passengers crowding around one tiny whiteboard while an airport worker on a radio wrote down the latest details. Photos also showed employees standing in front of another boards in the departure lounge looking clearly stressed out as they looked at information they had written down. On passenger sympathising with staff wrote on Twitter: Can you imagine how many languages are there trying to ask questions? I wish them luck and Calmness for all.    And one traveller posted: Serious whiteboard based business continuity going on in Gatwick. All flight information screens down. Poor chap with a 2-way radio trying to keep it up to date with hundreds looking on. Canadian passenger, mezzo-soprano Elizabeth Humphries, tweeted: Appalling Gatwick Airport, with broken monitors and a tiny whiteboard for announcing gates. title: inside hmp birmingham g4s run
story: NewsInside HMP Birmingham - the G4S-run jail where the inmates 'have taken over'Shocking videos taken inside the G4S-run prison show what it was like before the government was forced to step inShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDave Burke09:38, 20 AUG 2018Updated12:12, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith prisoners smoking drugs, listening to music and playing with their mobile phones, this is the inside of a jail where inmates have more power than staff. A clip taken inside HMP Birmingham this year shows one lag puffing on what appears to be a cannabis joint while others play pool. Another seemingly shows a prisoner slumped down after seemingly taking the drug Spice behind bars. The government has finally had enough of poor standards at the G4S-run jail, and has been forced to step in and take control. Inspectors found the prison in “an appalling state” with high violence, widespread bullying, squalid living conditions and poor control by fearful staff. In the video which emerged earlier this year, prisoners livestreamed themselves jokingly calling themselves the slider gang - due to their matching blue and white striped flip-flops. One man claims to have a bag of weed and a phone charger.  The video – entitled 'English jail inside with iPhones smoking Cali' – was uploaded by a user called Ray in April. It shows six prisoners lying on a bed in a cell while listening to music while another lag is seen smoking what appears to be a cannabis joint. One inmate repeatedly says Cali which is slang for cannabis, before warning that the screw is active, in reference to the prison guard. The video also shows a group of prisoners standing in the rubbish-strewn communal area outside the cells sharing around a rolled up cigarette while others play pool.  The prisoner shooting the video then comments jail life before turning the camera round and telling the viewer, we can get big thing, small thing. And another video, passed to Birmingham Live inFebruary, appears to show a motionless prisoner lying face down on their bed. It is believed he had taken Spice. Yet another shocking clip from November last year shows prisoners eating cockroaches in a twisted I’m A Celebrity… Get Me Out Of Here! inspired game.  Disturbing footage shows one inmate declare “I’m A Celebrity, get me out of HMP Birmingham!” as he is dared to scoff the insects in a mock bushtucker trial . The creatures appear to have been plucked from the floor and placed on a plastic tray - just like the ITV reality show. The MoJ decision to take over the prison comes as the chief prisons inspector has invoked a special measure calling on the Justice Secretary David Gauke to launch an urgent and independent enquiry into the crisis. In a letter sent to David Gauke on 16 August, Peter Clarke demanded an explanation for how the prison had “been allowed to deteriorate so dramatically” since its last inspection 18 months ago.  Inspectors found that out of the 70 recommendations made at the previous inspection - just 14 had been achieved while none of the main recommendations concerning violence, staff-prisoner relationships, poor regimes and a lack of focus on education, training and work had been met. The damning letter reveals a catalogue of failures and paints a picture of a total loss of control on the part of the G4S management. HMP Birmingham has the largest volume of assaults (1,434) of all prisons in the year to July 2018. Experts found that the assaults were often serious and that prisoners and staff frequently needed hospital treatment.

title: jamie oliver slammed mp latest
story: NewsJamie Oliver's jerk rice slammed as 'cultural appropriation' by Labour MPThe TV chef has launched a new range of products, including 'punchy jerk rice' which has so far been a recipe for disaster on social mediaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer18:43, 19 AUG 2018Updated07:19, 20 AUG 2018NewsJamie Oliver has been accused of 'cultural appropriation' (Image: Getty)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJamie Oliver has been slammed by critics on social media over a new range of products that includes punchy jerk rice. People have been quick to point out that jerk seasoning doesn't typically go on rice - but chicken, fish and other meats. The TV chef has been accused of cultural appropriation by people on social media, including Labour MP Dawn Butler, the shadow women and equalities minister. She wrote on Twitter that the celeb's jerk rice is not OK and that his appropriation from Jamaica needs to stop, adding that jerk is not just a word you put before stuff to sell products.      She also wrote that Jamie Oliver should get a masterclass in jerk by Levi Roots, the creator of Reggae Reggae sauce. Jerk is a type of cooking that originates in Jamaica, where meat is dry-rubbed or marinated in a seasoning made up of all spice, scotch bonnets and other ingredients. People accused him of cultural appropriation because the ingredients aren't traditional. One Twitter user wrote: I was about to headbutt my desk over this tweet from Dawn Butler because most cultural appropriation brouhahas are nonsense.  Then I saw this description of Jamie Oliver's Jerk Rice. On what planet can garlic, ginger and jalapenos be described as Jerk?' Some people have been quick to jump to Jamie Oliver's defence: arguing that the UK is a multicultural country and cooking different cuisines isn't the same as cultural appropriation. One person tweeted: Now while I do think Jamie needs taking down a peg or three you're all getting very silly over this appropriation stuff. If no one cooked/ate food from other cultures in the world what a boring life we'd lead.

title: motorist returns parked car find
story: NewsMotorist returns to parked car to find giant HOLE after ScottishPower digs up road and moves vehicle mile awayScottishPower said it is very rare that they move vehicles and that they did so "to carry out emergency repairs" - but they left Edinburgh Fringe-goer Lawrence Rivers strandedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKeith McLeodThomas Dean11:45, 20 AUG 2018Updated11:47, 20 AUG 2018NewsMr Rivers was reunited with his Mercedes 12 hours after it originally went missing (Image: David Johnstone Photography)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Edinburgh Fringe-goer was left stranded in the street after ScottishPower dug up the road beneath his parked car and moved it a mile away. Lawrence Rivers had been in town to take part in the comedy shows but it was no laughing matter when it took him 12 HOURS to find his vehicle. The businessman woke up at around at 7am on Saturday morning and posted the keys through his hotel letter box only to find himself carless. Armed with all his belongings Mr Rivers was was confronted with a gaping hole in the road where his Mercedes Benz once was and a phone number pinned to a lamp post.  It wasn't until his wife, Asha, finally got in touch with a vehicle recovery company that Mr Rivers was re-united with his car, Daily Records reports.   The 52-year-old said: “I spent hours walking the streets but there’s no way I would have found the car without Asha phoning round the vehicle recovery companies. Even then, the details of where it had been taken were a bit vague. “It was so random.” The father-of-one, from Leicestershire, left his Airbnb digs in Dryden Street on Saturday morning to drive home. He was carrying clothes on hangers, his toiletries bag and his case – and he had posted the keys through the letterbox after locking up. Mr Rivers said: “It was about 7am and I was standing in a street in Edinburgh with all the belongings I had for the trip. Where my car should have been there was a big hole. “I couldn’t drive home and I couldn’t go back to the accommodation.  “On a lamp post, a sign had been left with a number to call. I called and left a message but never got a call back. “When I phoned ScottishPower, I couldn’t get through to the proper department. When I eventually did, a recorded message said their office hours were Monday to Friday. “ScottishPower didn’t tell the police where they had moved it to. “At first, the police said they would find out for me. But a few hours into the search, they said they had drawn a blank. It was a comedy all of its own.” Mr Rivers phoned Asha, 46, to help him find the motor.

title: mums breastfeeding babies water swimming
story: NewsMums breastfeeding babies in water at swimming pool slam staff who asked them to leaveNatalie Forester and Chloe Hattersley were feeding their children during baby swim sessions at a pool in Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent - before being asked to sit on the side while feedingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlmi Redfern08:25, 20 AUG 2018Updated10:35, 20 AUG 2018NewsNatalie Forester was breastfeeding 18-month-old son Josiah in the swimming pool (Image: Stoke Sentinel)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMums have slammed a council after pool staff asked them to leave the water while they breastfed their babies in the pool. Natalie Forester and Chloe Hattersley were feeding their children during baby swim sessions at Dimensions pool in Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent. They were then stopped by staff who asked them to leave the pool while breastfeeding and sit on the side. Stoke-on-Trent City Council, which runs Dimensions, says breastfeeding is welcome at the poolside, but is ‘discouraged’ in its swimming pools ‘for the health and comfort of the child and to avoid the risk of the child regurgitating or vomiting in the pool’.  But Natalie and Chloe say this policy does not make sense and is at odds with the Equality Act 2010, reports Stoke-on-Trent Live .   Mother-of-three Natalie, of Sneyd Green, was at an Aquatots session with her 18-month-old son Josiah when she was stopped from feeding. The 30-year-old said: “There were about five other parents in the pool with their children. The rest of the pool was closed to the public. “Josiah was distressed so I thought I would give him some milk. I thought if we got out he would get cold, so I moved away and turned my back to the group. I was only going to feed him for a couple of minutes to comfort him. “The teacher came over and said I couldn’t do it in the pool and I would have to sit on the side. I was made to feel like I was doing something wrong. “I didn’t want a confrontation so I moved, which I’m annoyed about now. I felt degraded.” Natalie asked for a copy of Dimensions’ breast-feeding policy, and found the rule under the Food and Beverage section.  She said: “Stoke-on-Trent has one of the lowest breast-feeding rates in the country and they should be encouraging people, not doing this.” First-time mum Chloe, of Middleport, had a similar experience while at an Aquatots session with her 17-month-old son Milo. The 19-year-old said: “I have breastfed in the water before, but on this occasion a lifeguard shouted across the pool to me to stop doing it. “Everyone was staring. Normally I would stand my ground, but I was really embarrassed so I just got out. “I’ve made an offical complaint. I don’t see how the council’s policy can override the law – it’s discrimination.” The Equality Act 2010 says it is discrimination to treat a woman unfavourably because she is breastfeeding.

title: people giving up black cats
story: AdvertorialPeople are giving up black cats for adoption for this unbelievable reasonApparently they don't photograph well for social mediaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Masters00:00, 20 AUG 2018Updated10:12, 20 AUG 2018AdvertorialWe're going to be telling the stories of how some seemingly unadoptable cats have found their perfect matchGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf you visit your local Cats Protection Centre today, you'll come across one type of feline much more than others. And where it was once superstition or the fear of bad luck that got cats with black fur overlooked, apparently people are now blaming the fact they don’t photograph well for social media photographs. Cats Protection help around 200,000 cats in their centres every year and for most moggies it's not long at all before they find a new home. But unfortunately, some in their care - such as black and white, shy, those with a minor or pre-existing medical condition or older cats - often have to wait a little longer than others.  For example, cats aged 15 years or older take an extra 28 days longer to home than kittens. However, the animal lovers at Purina and Cats Protection believe no cat is unadoptable and over the coming weeks we'll be telling the stories of how some seemingly unadoptable cats have found their perfect match.  Purina and Cats Protection have been working together since the 1980s. In that time, Cats Protection have expanded to include over 250 volunteer-run branches and 36 adoption centres across the country. Cats Protection do an amazing job of keeping all the cats in their care warm, safe and nourished all year round, while Purina are behind some of the nation’s favorite cat food brands including Gourmet, Felix, Purina One and Go-Cat - but they're much more than a pet food company.  Purina's big-hearted staff are passionate about improving the lives of pets, with promoting pet adoption through collaborations and partnership one of the company's 10 Purina commitments to pets and society. story: NewsRare £2 Charles Dickens coin sells on eBay for whopping £3,500 - and you could have one sitting in YOUR homeThere are 8.1 million of the 2012 coin in circulation - but this one is one of a few that are considered a "coin collector's dream" thanks to two minting errorsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBriana Millett09:30, 20 AUG 2018Updated12:46, 20 AUG 2018NewsA rare coin has just sold for £3,500 on eBay - do you have one? (Image: Ebay)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA rare &pound2 coin has just sold on eBay for thousands of pounds - and you could have one sitting in your home without even knowing it. The coin, which incorporate the titles of Dickens’ famous works, sold for a staggering &pound3,500 on Tuesday August 14, according to Bristol Live . Charles Dickens is known as one of the greatest writers of the Victorian era, but despite the high-selling price of this coin the Charles Dickens &pound2 coin is actually quite common, according to checkyourchange . With a mintage for circulation of 8,1 million, it has the lowest rating of 'one' for collectability and scarcity. However, this particular coin has been described as a coin collector's dream thanks to a few minting errors.  The coin has been made even rarer because dots around Queen Elizabeth's head disappear half way around, and the milled wording around the coin is upside down. The seller, going by the name climbing_uk, posted on the website: In 2012, the Royal Mint issued a &pound2 coin to celebrate the 200th anniversary of Charles, one of Britain’s finest writers, with a unique &pound2 coin that incorporates the titles of Dickens’ famous works on its highly inventive reverse.

title: ryanair passenger stand crew over
story: NewsRyanair passenger in stand-off with crew when he's asked to pay for box of Pringles after four-hour delayJohnny McMenamin, 36, was travelling with his five year-old daughter when he asked cabin crew for a free bottle of water and Pringles following heir delay ordeal at Reus airport in SpainShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCiara Colhoun09:21, 20 AUG 2018Updated09:55, 20 AUG 2018NewsJohnny and his daughter were delayed for nearly five hours (Image: Internet Unknown)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Ryanair passenger found himself in a stand-off with cabin crew after they tried to make him pay for a box of Pringles following a four-and-a-half hour delay. Johnny McMenamin, 36, and his five year-old daughter were delayed at Reus airport in Spain for two hours last Monday, before spending nearly three hours on board the plane while it sat on the runway. They had been due to take off at 9.45pm for East Midlands Airport where they planned to go to a theme park the following day before making their way back home to Co Tyrone, in Northern Ireland.  Johnny said he was horrified that airline staff insisted he pay for a bottle of water and Pringles for his child when they finally took off, reports Belfast Live .  The father said he was even accused of stealing from the bar in an announcement from the pilot.  He said: After eventually boarding two hours late we didn't go anywhere for another two hours 45 minutes. Staff were rude and people were having to ask for water. By the time we took off my daughter was distressed and tired. Johnny said the dispute arose when he realised, after chatting to another passenger, that he had missed an offer of vouchers for refreshments that were distributed in the departure lounge. He claimed flight attendants on board refused to give him the same vouchers afforded to other passengers. He said: I couldn't believe they were trying to charge me for a snack for a child when we had been delayed for 4 hours 39 minutes. It was the early hours of the morning, my daughter was hungry and exhausted. I told them it was a welfare package I was looking for at that stage, not a menu. I asked for a bottle of water and Pringles for my daughter and they insisted I needed to pay &pound5.50, which I refused out of principal.

title: super saver woman saved 15000
story: NewsSuper savvy woman saves £15,000 and even buys a house after collecting discount couponsSavvy Clair Hughes, 30, started researching ways to save money as a way of getting out of her £3,500 overdraft before stumbling upon a 'couponing' community onlineShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByErin Cardiff07:56, 20 AUG 2018Updated12:34, 20 AUG 2018NewsClair estimates she's saved over £15,000 (Image: PA Real Life)Get Money Deals updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman saved &pound15,000 and bought a house after collecting thousands of discount coupons online. Savvy Clair Hughes, 30, started researching ways to save money as a way of getting out of her &pound3,500 overdraft. During her search, Clair, from Bury, Greater Manchester, stumbled upon a 'couponing' community online - and was hooked. Clair now estimates she’s saved “easily over &pound15,000” - and even managed to put down a deposit to buy a three-bed semi-detached house with her partner, Shane Byrne, also 30. Revealing how she never pays full price for an item anymore, thrifty Clair, who works in a local school, said: “It’s become a running joke with my friends. Every time we go out, they’ll ask if I have a voucher – and I always do. “Discounts are always there to be had, it’s just a matter of being organised.  “Before I started this, I thought it’d be so much work, but now I’m so used to this lifestyle that it’s automatic to me. I must have saved easily over &pound15,000.” Clair’s mind first turned to money saving back in 2010, when she moved in with Shane, a phone company trainer. Having recently graduated from Edge Hill University, near Wigan, where she studied drama and physical theatre, she’d maxed out her &pound3,500 student overdraft – and felt the interest repayments were just “money down the drain.” After taking to the web for advice, she tried out a few clever money saving tricks like switching her overdraft to a zero-interest account. Then, a few years later, she came across an online community for “couponers” and decided to give it a go.  She started spending hours trawling the web for money off vouchers or discount codes, printing them all out to take with her whenever she went shopping. “It would initially take a couple of hours to get organised,” she said. “I’d go on supermarket websites to look through what I’d need in a shop, making a note of anything on offer, or anything I had a coupon for. “Eventually though it becomes second nature and you can do it in around half an hour.” Over the years, the coupon queen has managed to nab some impressive hauls. Two lamps worth &pound140 cost her just &pound35, and because she learnt buying in bulk is usually cheaper, she scored six months worth of dog food for her Pomeranian Poppy for a mere &pound9. Around two years ago, Clair also began using cashback apps and websites where you are given money back on items ranging from beers to toiletries.  After each shop, she uploads pictures of her receipts, which are then scanned, and money is given back on certain items. “I’ve saved hundreds through that alone,” said bargain-mad Clair. “You can get cashback on most things, and it’s all something I’d have been buying anyway. If something is totally free, I always make sure I get it regardless of whether I’ll use it, as I can donate it to a charity or foodbank. “But with cashback, I make sure it’s worth my while.” Among her other top saving tips, Clair recommends taking part in paid online surveys, which have earned her hundreds in high street vouchers, hitting the shops at certain times of the day to take advantage of reduced ‘yellow sticker’ stock, signing up to receive trials or tester products or trawling cosmetics counters for freebies. She added: “I have managed to get a lot of freebies by messaging or writing to companies to compliment them on their products. People always assume you get freebies for complaining – but it pays more to be nice.  “I’ve heard a lot about a practice called wombling too, which is basically collecting other people’s discarded receipts from shopping trolleys to check for missed discounts.  I’d love to give it a try but there doesn’t seem to be a receipt to be found at my local supermarket.” Having set herself the goal of owning a home by the time she was 30, Clair - who has set up an Instagram dedicated to sharing her thrifty pearls of wisdom - was delighted to exchange just five days shy of her landmark birthday. And now, after Shane proposed to her on his birthday earlier in August, she is looking ahead to planning the ultimate shoestring wedding.

story: News'Tough cookie' 95-year-old injured after bravely taking on FIVE thugs who broke into her homeThe pensioner was shoved to the ground after a group of teenagers climbed into her home in Manchester on Thursday nightShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCharlotte Dobson11:22, 20 AUG 2018NewsThe incident happened in Homewood Road in the Northenden area of Manchester (general view)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 'tough cookie' 95-year-old has been injured after bravely taking on five teenage thugs who broke into her home at night. story: NewsUK Bank holiday weather forecast: Temperatures set to plunge as torrential showers spell grim weekendAfter a scorching summer, with temperatures well above average in most parts, forecasters are predicting a much chillier end to AugustShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrett Gibbons12:10, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBank holiday temperatures are set to plunge as torrential showers spell a grim weekend ahead. Latest computer models suggest frequent showers and longer spells of rain in the north and west, while drier, brighter periods are expected further south. After several weeks of persistent above-normal temperatures, the mercury is expected to dip well below average in some areas.  “From Thursday, things are expected to turn cooler with the chilliest day of the weekend on Saturday. As the high continues to extend eastwards, it bring a more westerly flow over the British Isles. “Temperatures will start to recover by Sunday.” Leading bookmaker Coral makes it odds on, at 4-5, that rain falls over the Bank Holiday weekend in London despite some warm temperatures forecast.
