title: uk weather met office forecast
story: NewsUK weather Met Office forecast: Brits to swelter again with temperatures soaring to 28C in the southThe UK will return to more humid, muggy weather in the run-up to the last Bank Holiday weekend of the yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire Gilbody-Dickerson19:43, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The UK is braced for another bout of hot, sticky weather with temperatures soaring in the south by midweek, according to the Met Office.  After a brief respite and some very welcome rain, the country will return to more humid, muggy weather in the run-up to the last Bank Holiday weekend of the year. Monday will begin with sunny spells in Scotland and northern England. Central areas will see spots of rain with cloud building in the north and rain spells expected after 12pm. But the Met said they won’t be “long-lived or heavy”, and that light winds will bring temperatures in the north to 22C and 26C in the south.   Yet the cooler weather isn’t bound to last long as the Met Office said it will be “quite humid and muggy through Tuesday and Wednesday”.  Highs of 26C are expected in the north, while the south may reach 27C or 28C depending on the sunshine. Londoners are also set for another 25C heatwave on Wednesday, but the Met said it’ll feel fresher because of rain, before it cools down to 20C on Friday.  It comes after the UK was battered by Storm Ernesto over the weekend, with the north being the worst hit and the Met forecasting up two-and-a-half inches of rain.     Met Office forecaster Steven Keates said: “Ernesto’s warm and humid air stays here for the first half of the week, with 26-28C from Monday to Wednesday in the South, with mainly dry weather for most. “A cold front brings rain on Thursday, but the Bank Holiday weekend looks relatively warm at 23C and a degree or two warmer not ruled out. “The South will be mainly dry, and the North still seeing good sunny spells, but less settled.” UV levels will be high or moderate across the country, while pollen levels will remain low. Summer 2018 has a chance of ending up the warmest on record for the UK, with the race for the top spot wide open, according to the Met Office.

title: uk weather summer hottest 359
story: NewsUK weather: Summer 'hottest for 359 years' with mercury higher than 1976, and 1666 Great Fire of London summerThis summer is set to be the warmest since UK-wide records began in 1910 with an average maximum temperature of more than 21CShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlistair GrantTom DavidsonOnline Reporter13:13, 20 AUG 2018NewsBathing ponds and lidos, like this one in Hampstead Heath, London, were busy today (Image: PA)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email This summer is verging on the hottest for 359 years – hotter than 1976’s sizzler and even 1666’s Great Fire of London summer.   Met Office figures show these warm months are on track to be the hottest since UK-wide records began in 1910.  Temperatures from June 1 to August 15 averaged 16.1C, hotter than 2006’s record 15.78C from June 1 to August 31. This summer’s average maximum temperature of 21.1C so far is also hotter than 1976’s record 21C. The soaring temperatures have seen packed beaches and parks - and also a surge in the number of sunburn cases reported to the NHS.   But Met Office figures also show the average temperature since June 1 is nudging the hottest since the world's oldest temperature records began 359 years ago in 1659 in central England, covering 25 million people in the area enclosed by the Thames, Lancashire and Bristol.  28C (83F) heat this week is set to increase August’s average temperature. This summer will beat 1976’s record 17.77C in central England if August’s average temperature rises just 0.3C from 17.9C to 18.2C by the end of the month.    This summer is set to eclipse 2003’s scorcher as well as older hot summers including drought-ravaged 1826 and 1781, and 1666, when the Great Fire of London ripped through the tinder-dry city. Met Office forecaster Steven Keates said: “It's been a damn good summer and the best I can remember. It’s one we’ll remember for many years. All parts of the UK have seen good weather. “Warm weather in coming days favours this summer challenging to become the hottest UK-wide summer on record.” It's no secret that hot weather can wreak havoc with your skin.  From oily sun lotion to air conditioning units - there’s no shortage of ways the summer can take a toll on your complexion.  But what does the hot weather really do to your skin, and how can you protect it? Candice Brown, specialist skin aesthetician at London Bridge Plastic Surgery and Aesthetic Clinic, gives her top tips on how to survive the summer with glowing skin.  Sun damage Candice says: “Damage from the sun is obviously the biggest threat to your skin during the summer months. “In hot weather even though most people will wear an SPF, if we sit in the sun all day it doesn’t matter how much sun lotion you apply to your skin - you are never going to stop the damage from occurring. “Alongside a good SPF I always recommend clients should be using a product that can repair the skin’s barrier. A good serum in addition to a product that can keep the skin hydrated is a must. “It’s also important to find a shaded area during the hottest hours of the day. I know some people are desperate for a tan, but you can still get a healthy glow by wearing an SPF and placing yourself in areas shielded from direct sunlight. “The short term effect that sun damage can cause to your skin just isn’t worth it irritation, redness and sensitivity. Sun damage and dehydration can also result in longer term effects such as the formation of fine lines and wrinkles, as well as pigmentation concerns.” Sudden temperate changes Candice says: “During the hot weather it’s not uncommon to go from direct sunlight to a really cool, air conditioned office.  “But going from hot to cold too quickly can cause redness and thread veins on the skin. I would say from midday to 3pm to try and avoid being in direct sunlight. This should reduce the threat of such extreme changes in temperature.” Sea and sand The beach can be a welcome break during a heatwave, but it’s not without its risks.  Candice says: “The sea and sand can be really irritating to the skin. On top of this, the salt in sea water is drying and can cause the skin to become quite sensitive.  “When the skin loses hydration it can lose brightness, leaving your skin looking very dull!”.  “I would recommend using products with Hydroxy Acid such as serums and toners to keep the skin hydrated at all times. If you’re going on holiday, take a repair masque to help with any damage that has been caused to the skin barrier from the sun that day.  “These products can easily be placed into your beach bag to keep your skin hydrated throughout the day. And make sure you’re drinking two to three litres of water every day.  Makeup Think you’re protecting your skin because your favourite foundation contains an SPF? Think again.  Candice says: “Don’t rely on make-up for the best source of SPF. “Unless you’re re-applying a really thick layer of makeup you’re not going to be getting a full SPF coverage. Make-up isn’t always applied evenly and it can come off easily throughout the day.  “You should be applying a separate SPF in the morning and then if you want to apply a tint afterwards then you can. This way you know every inch of your face is going to be covered and protected.” Pool water  Candice says: “The chlorine found in swimming pool water can make your eyes feel sensitive, and it can do the same to your skin.  “Chlorine tends to strip the skin of natural oils leaving your skin dry, itchy, flaky, and sensitive. So it’s really important to reach for a lotion or serum with alpha hydroxy acid to hydrate and help restore the pH balance of your skin”. Air conditioning It might be a blessing during a heatwave, but air conditioning units aren’t all good news.  Candice says: “Air conditioning in both the summer and the winter can cause problems, and can definitely affect your skin.  “It can dry it out making the skin feel tight and very dehydrated. So you probably feel as if you need to be using a lot more products to keep it looking and feeling healthy.  “Anti-oxidants through the summer and winter months are a must. Vitamin C is not only necessary for collagen production and maintenance, but also a potent antioxidant that can neutralise free radicals in the skin. “A good vitamin C serum and an SPF 30/50 are two products I would advise to apply to the skin before leaving the house” The Met Office’s Dr Mark McCarthy said: “It’s clear summer 2018 is exceptional for the consistent levels of warmth throughout the period.” Unfortunately the weather will not stay good for the upcoming Bank Holiday. Forecasters are predicting a much chillier end to August.

title: upton park shoppers wrestle blade
story: NewsUpton Park shoppers wrestle blade from hands of knifeman before he is pinned to the floorA knife was wrestled from a teenager after he allegedly stabbed a man in the middle of a busy street in broad daylightShare&nbspByLaura Forsyth13:52, 19 AUG 2018Updated14:03, 19 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHero bystanders are seen wrestling a knife from a youth after he allegedly stabbed a man in the hand in the middle of a east London high street. A shocking video clip shows two men trying to grab the weapon off a the suspect in broad daylight near Upton Park Tube station. Terrified passersby look on as the youth pushes the group from the pavement, and into the path of approaching traffic. Another then bravely runs to their help and attempts to stop the suspect holding the knife. Dashcam footage shows the incident happening behind a bus in the middle of Green Street, shortly before 1pm on Saturday.  A man with a shopping bag and a fourth stop and join the struggle as they attempt to grab the knife safely out of the way. Another appears to have been hurt by the knife and runs off the road, where a queue of cars are waiting. Then the clip shows the group of men, who appear to be in their 30s and 40s, holding onto the suspect until a another person in grey tracksuit bottoms takes the knife from him. Finally the weapons spins dramatically through the air. Near the end of the video, the youth is seen throwing another bystander onto a car.  Then one of the group places the knife safely back in the scabbard. A second clip shows one of the men who helped holding his bleeding hand with a bandage. Meanwhile police appear to hold the suspect to the ground, which is covered with blood. A Met Police spokesman said: Police in Newham were called to Green Street, E13 at 12:50hrs on Saturday, 18 August following reports of a fight.

title: voice mirror stop pwc cashing
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: 'Stop PwC cashing in on Carillion'The scandal of private contractor Carillion’s collapse goes from bad to worse with the revelation accountancy giant Price Waterhouse Coopers is charging up to £1,156 an hourShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByVoice of the Mirror01:18, 20 AUG 2018NewsopinionThe Carillion saga continues (Image: Liverpool Echo)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe scandal of private contractor Carillion’s collapse goes from bad to worse as the vultures feed on the corpse of a firm which owes taxpayers a fortune and left thousands of workers without jobs. Accountancy giant PwC charging up to &pound1,156 an hour feels as excessive as the Unite union claims, especially when concerns about the company’s previous work were raised by MPs Frank Field and Rachel Reeves, joint heads of a Parliamentary inquiry that accused the auditor of a conflict of interest. Field’s dig that PwC had “every incentive to milk the Carillion cow dry” is reinforced by the eyewatering invoices. The insistence by a financial behemoth that the cost would otherwise be higher will only infuriate victims of a terrible corporate failure. Carillion was an ugly face of capitalism, run for the benefit of a few at the price of the many. PwC is not covering itself in glory.  Theresa May has not just abandoned a Tory promise to get rid of mixed sex hospital wards but gone in total reverse. Close on 15,000 patients had to share wards with the opposite sex last year, a betrayal of 2010 and 2015 Tory manifesto promises. Uncaring May does not seem to care about stripping NHS patients of their privacy. What might be acceptable occasionally in exceptional emergencies is not OK when it happens because of poor management or because austerity cuts have forced hospitals to shed beds. Until the Tories sort simpler problems such as the banning of mixed wards they have no chance of finding a cure for the bigger issues.

title: why deleted tinder after week
story: News'Why I deleted Tinder after a week even though I found it's not just loads of people looking for easy sex'Katie-Ann Gupwell tried the dating app and said: "I thought Tinder was rife with people sending unwanted explicit images, flirting and basically finding people to have sex with"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKatie-Ann Gupwell07:32, 20 AUG 2018Updated07:37, 20 AUG 2018NewsKatie-Ann Gupwell gave Tinder a go for a week (Image: Katie-Ann Gupwell)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKatie-Ann Gupwell, a reporter at MirrorOnline's sister website WalesOnline, went on Tinder for a week - this is what happened in her words: When people find out I'm 24 and single, I get told a lot: You should get on Tinder. In truth I'd never fancied it myself, but in 2018, Tinder and other apps, like Bumble, seem to be the way to meet people. Personally I prefer talking to faces instead of typing on a screen - and there's something that's quite scary about the idea of meeting someone that you've never met in person. But I downloaded it in an attempt to see what the modern world of dating is really like, and recounted the experience on Wales Online.  As little as two weeks ago, I thought Tinder was rife with people sending unwanted explicit images, flirting and basically finding people to have sex with. But apparently it's not (just) about that. Still, all over the internet, there are horror stories about people's experiences. One woman described being sent a picture of a penis with a measuring tape next to it by a guy she met, another described being given chlamydia by a guy who she later found out was already in relationships with two other women. In Wales, a would-be consultant harassed a woman he met on Tinder, sending her emails and hacking her Facebook account . While cases like this may be rare (at least, I hope they are), there's still good reason to be wary and it was hard to go into this with confidence. But at least you can't send pictures on the app. I found this out from a fellow user about an hour after downloading it - for that to happen I would have to add them on another form of social media such as Snapchat or Instagram . Sweet joy! I did not have to put myself through seeing genitals of various shapes and sizes for the purpose of this experiment. Saying that, the fear soon upped when I accidentally super-liked about three people in the space of the first hour. Not ideal.  From the get-go I knew I was never going to meet up with anyone - but as soon as I started swiping I could see what to avoid: 1. People without profile pictures. Why would you not show your face? 2. People with odd profile pictures. I saw everything from a set of sex toys to a quote that read 'I want to do bad things to you' to a chicken nugget. An actual chicken nugget. None of which encouraged me to swipe right. 3. People who had their hands down their pants in pictures. 4. People who are open about wanting hook-ups in their bios. If you like a six pack - you'll see a lot of them on Tinder. There are a lot of guys who post topless pictures of themselves or snaps of them working out at the gym. A lot also posted selfies with their dogs (I know what you're trying to do!) and kids, before quickly pointing out they were their nephews or nieces (Hey, I love kids but I don't have any of my own). During my short stint, I had one or two requests to add guys on Instagram but I gracefully declined. What I found more intriguing is that a lot of people don't actually talk on Tinder.

title: chris watts request dna swabs
story: NewsChris Watts' request for DNA swabs from dead daughters' necks REFUSED as prosecutors prepare to reveal motiveChris Watts, 33, will appear in court today charged with murdering daughters Bella, four, and Celeste, three, and wife Shanann, who was 15-weeks pregnant with a baby boyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop10:59, 20 AUG 2018Updated12:21, 20 AUG 2018NewsChris Watts, 33, will appear in court today charged with murdering daughters Bella, four, and Celeste, three and wife Shanann (Image: Instagram)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailInvestigators are today set to reveal the reasons they believe a father murdered his pregnant wife and two daughters.  Chris Watts, 33, will appear in court today charged with murdering daughters Bella, four, and Celeste, three and wife Shanann, who was 15-weeks pregnant with a baby boy that they were going to name Nico.  Following his arrest on Wednesday his lawyer requested for DNA swabs to be taken from his dead daughters' necks. On Friday it was revealed the request had been refused, with a judge saying he 'won't tell experts how to do their job.'  Last week Watts sobbed on TV as he appealed for the return of the trio before allegedly confessing he had killed them - but the cause of their death has not been made officially public.   The bodies were found on the property of Anadarko Petroleum, one of Colorado's largest oil and gas drillers where Watts worked. Court documents filed by defence lawyer James Merson said the girls had been submerged in crude oil for four days. His lawyers said the DNA would be tested by forensics expert Richard Eikelenboom, who worked on the JonBenet Ramsey trial. But his lawyer Megan Ring said in a two-page filing to a court in Weld County, Colorado, that a 'coroner, pathologist, or anyone working on behalf of the prosecution team in autopsy' don't plan to take swabs of the necks of the two girls.  Ring had asked that DNA expert Eikelenboom be allowed to do the testing, saying that they believed that DNA would remain on the necks of the girls 'in spite of the fact that the remains were in oil for four days' - revealing for the first time that the bodies were hidden on Monday. Autopsies on the bodies were conducted Friday, although an official cause of death has not been announced - although it is believed the request from Watts' defence team suggests they could have been strangled. A body language expert who closely studied the recordings of the interviews said last week that they thought it was apparent that the 'killer' dad was lying.  Lillian Glass told HollywoodLife that Watts' spoke too much and was giving out too much information.   He said at the time: I have no inclination where they're at right now. I've exhausted every friend that I know of and every friend that I have has called friends that Shanann has that maybe I didn't know about. ... Just vanished. When I got home yesterday it was like a ghost town. She wasn't here. The kids were here. I have no idea where they went.  A former FBI profiler Mary Ellen O'Toole also said his interview showed arrogance and a lack of empathy.  She said: When somebody kills their own family and then they go on TV to say 'But I didn't have anything to do with it,' that ability to be so very sure of your own interpersonal skills that you can attempt to fool a national and international audience is very unusual.

title: couples haunting blog posts human
story: NewsCouple's haunting blog posts on human kindness before being killed in ISIS attack while on dream trip around worldJay Austin and Lauren Geoghegan's heartbreaking blog said they believed humans were kind, wonderful and generousShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter12:02, 20 AUG 2018NewsJay Austin and Lauren Geoghegan quit their jobs for a world trip (Image: Simply Cycling)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A couple who were killed in an ISIS -claimed attack on their dream trip had blogged about strangers' acts of kindness while they travelled.  Jay Austin and Lauren Geoghegan decided to quit their office jobs to cycle around the world, having grown tired of meetings and wanting an adventure.  The American couple, both 29, wrote about their moments of 'human connection' with strangers along the way, on a shared blog and in Instagram posts.  Jay insisted he believed humans were kind, wonderful and generous - despite what 'you read in the papers about the world being a scary place'.  But the holiday of a lifetime ended tragically on July 29 when a vehicle rammed into them as they cycled on a panoramic stretch of road in southwestern Tajikistan, the Independent reports .   It was on day 369 of their trip that Jay and Lauren were killed along with two other cyclists from Switzerland and the Netherlands. The car is believed to have aimed directly at the bikers. And two days later, IS reportedly released a video vowing 'to kill disbelievers'. As they travelled, Jay had written on their blog: Evil is a make-believe concept we’ve invented to deal with the complexities of fellow humans holding values and beliefs and perspectives different than our own … By and large, humans are kind.  He blogged: “You get a feeling of wanting to give back, not just to this person who has welcomed a stranger into their home, but to the wider world. Jay, who met Lauren in 2012 in Washington, also wrote: “There’s magic out there, in this great big beautiful world.” On their journey, they were handed free ice cream, treated to an open air concert, and given a bouquet of flowers by two young girls in Kyrgyzstan.

title: british woman holidaying croatia hostel
story: NewsBritish woman on holiday at Croatia hostel is beaten with a metal pole after refusing to pay more moneyLondon student Laura Denmar, 26, needed stitches after the attack in Split and has warned others about shady operators after booking online through a Dublin-based websiteShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex Shipman10:45, 20 AUG 2018Updated11:47, 20 AUG 2018NewsLaura Denman in hospital after the attack in Croatia (Image: Laura Denman / SWNS)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British student was seriously hurt in a horrific attack with a metal bar - after she refused to pay more money for her holiday hostel. Laura Denmar, 26, was taken to hospital and needed stitches following the brutal attack, which also saw her boyfriend pinned to a wall. She had to have emergency hospital treatment after the attack in the Croatian resort of Split - and has now warned others about shady accommodation operators. The couple have cut short their month-long trip. Laura said: “We are doing okay now that we are back in the UK, but it was a really terrifying ordeal. “It was clear that the entire operation was not legal in the first place - and the attack was definitely premeditated. Have you had a similar experience while on holiday? Contact webnews@trinitymirror  “We are lucky to be out of there and want to warn others before they book accommodation online. Laura, a student at London’s Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, travelled to Croatia last month with boyfriend Jeremy, 39. She and the Canadian videographer booked a &pound60-a-night hostel through a major website because of peak season hotel prices. But when they arrived in the city’s picturesque Old Town, on the Dalmatian coast, they were immediately sent away to a grimy suburb.  She said: We were told that we had to pick up the keys from a different hostel, and then make our way to the apartment. When we arrived we realised that it was not legitimate at all – there were 30 beds and only one bathroom and no one there running anything. We had nowhere else to stay and we had already paid so we decided to make do. On the last day, a cleaner came in early and told us that we needed to leave right away or pay more money. I told her that was unreasonable and refused to hand over any money and so she told us she would call the police if we did not leave. I knew what they were doing was illegal so I told her to go on and call the police. Instead she called a man who we think was the owner.

title: two week old baby girl
story: NewsTwo-week-old baby girl found abandoned in cardboard box alongside blankets, milk bottle and hidden noteInside the box was a hidden note, revealing the baby's birth dateShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByScott FengAmber Hicks13:14, 20 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA newborn baby girl has been found abandoned on the side of a road in a cardboard box wrapped in blankets with a bottle of milk. The 16-day-old was discovered by passing motorists who saw her wriggling in the box, nestled on pink and blue blankets, and heard her cries. When they lifted her out to comfort her, they also discovered a hidden note, which read: The baby girl was born on 4th August 2018. The residents alerted police and took care of the newborn until officers arrived and took her to a hospital for treatment.  Medics say she is healthy and showed no apparent signs of illness or any birth defects. Good Samaritans have now been turning up to the hospital in South China hoping to adopt her. Local police, from Changmei in Huanjiang Maonan, confirmed the infant will remain with the authorities while they search for her mother or parents. If they are traced, they could face up to three years in jail if found guilty of abandonment.  It comes just days after a police officer in Argentina was praised for her act of kindness after breastfeeding a neglected smelly and dirty baby in hospital.

title: blether former dundee owner shares team photo featuring late friend dave young
story: A few weeks ago, former Dundee FC owner Peter Marr put out a plea for a photo of a Fintry Youth Club team with his great friend Dave Young in it.Dave, known to many in local football, pub and taxi circles, died recently.Peter managed to find a copy himself and now shares it with BwB (with “apologies for some of the spelling of names and quality of photo”).The team (above) is the U/16 team from around 1966.Back row (from left) — Gordon Deuchars, Dave Young, Jackie Connelly, Stan Jarcoski, Derek Stewart, Derek Meldrum. title: blether local baker steps in to save hibernian
story: Our July 7 tale of Hibs supremo Harry Swan divided comment.Hibs fan Ron Martin said he “loved” Rob Boag’s story, and agreed with his assertion that he, along with fellow-Easter Road director of the time Hugh Shaw, should be inducted into the SFA Hall of Fame.He opened: “I loved Rob Boag’s story about Harry Swan, Hugh Shaw and the Famous Five.“In the early 1930s, he saved Hibs from going under. The club had just been relegated and were in severe financial difficulties and Swan — Leith born and bred — stepped in.“He was a local baker and, after a couple of years of ‘toing-and-froing’ with the board, he was eventually elected chairman and would serve on the board for around 30 years. He produced a blueprint for the club and admitted it could take many years to come to fruition.“But it did — and European football and installing floodlights were some of his ground-breaking initiatives.Ron, from Carnoustie, continued: “He appointed Willie McCartney as team manager, and he would go on to unearth the Famous Five of Smith, Johnstone, Reilly, Turnbull and Ormond on to the Scottish scene.“Massive crowds attended home games at Easter Road and several league titles were won. He was also president of the SFA for a few years, but, like many before and after him, struggled to get ideas for the national game implemented.”

title: blether winning goal a mile offside but where is the team photograph
story: A plea for a photo to be published came from Grant Millar.Grant wanted BwB to locate the image of Dundee U/18 Schoolboys from 1983, when they contested the Scottish Cup Final.He made his plea through Grenville Dawson, who has supplied the Evening  for many decades with schools football information, results and fixtures — and still does!“Grant was at Monifieth High School and played right midfield,” said Grenville.“The team was run by Dave Beattie (Morgan Academy) and Bill Ferrier (Linlathen Secondary School).“The team reached the Senior National Trophy Final in 1983 and lost to Aberdeen Schoolboys 1-0.“The winning goal, according to Grant, was ‘a mile offside’.”Grenville intimated that some of the reminiscing below from Grant may be a bit hazy, given that it was 35 years ago.He continued: “It might have been the case that Dundee United manager Jim McLean presented the trophy to winning side Aberdeen.“Craig Brewster, of Harris Academy, and also of Forfar, Dundee United and others, was in the team.“Grant thinks that there was a defender from Harris there as well, very possibly John Young.“He also thinks goalkeeper Jim Butter, of Rockwell HS, who played for Alloa Athletic, Montrose, East Fife and Brechin City, among others, was in the squad, though he might not have played in any of the games.“The first-choice keeper then was Colin Blackley, of Lawside Academy, who was on Dundee FC’s books at the time.“However, Grant is not sure if he played in the final as two or three players left school to take up apprenticeships shortly before.“The only other name he remembers is another ‘maybe’ — and that was Robert Ogg, from Craigie High School, who was left midfield.”Dundee played Lothian Schools at Heriot-Watt in the first round, winning 3-0.The second round was away to North of Scotland at Lossiemouth, and they chalked up another 3-0 win.For the semi-final, the team travelled to tackle Ayrshire in Kilmarnock, which Dundee won by the only goal of the game.Arbroath was the venue for the final against Aberdeen, the game being played at Arbroath Vics’ Ogilvy Park in May 83.Aberdeen won 1-0.Unfortunately, despite searching, this photo can’t be located.As ever, if a BwB reader has one, then please send it in.

title: charity hopes to reopen indoor dundee market in next few weeks
story: The Hilltown Indoor Market could be set to reopen within the next few weeks – for the first time in more than 18 months.Plans are in place for the venue to operate as a charitable venture selling and donating furniture – with smaller individual traders taking spaces in the market.The building, on Main Street, closed on Christmas Eve 2016 to undergo refurbishment work, and was due to relaunch in March last year.However, the revamp never took place and it has remained shut ever since.In the interim, the charity Tayside Furniture Re-use Network has secured the lease for the building and contacted Dundee City Council.Smaller businesses will pay a set rate, which will go towards its upkeep and supporting the charity’s work.Gary Gallagher, a former trader at the market, has been working voluntarily to get the building back into a respectable condition.It is understood a building warrant has been issued and it’s hoped the market will reopen under its new identity in about four weeks.Gary said: “The plan was to open last year but there have been some hold-ups in terms of getting stuff rubber-stamped from the council.“I understand that warrants have been granted by the council and the go-ahead to open will be in a few weeks with Tayside Furniture Reuse Network taking over about 80-90% of the building.“As far as I know, the plan is to be open seven days a week.“The remaining spaces will be let out to antique dealers and smaller traders and hopefully the cafe will reopen.“The traders will pay a set fee every week to the charity to go towards the upkeep of the building. It’s absolutely great that the building is getting put to use again.“It won’t be the market it was, more of a charity base, with the smaller traders in some of the units.”Tayside Furniture Re-use Network was set up last year.With about 10 million household items sent to landfill every year in Scotland, the charity estimates three million items could be re-used by people in crisis.The Tayside Furniture Re-use Network will try to help reach vulnerable people in crisis by gathering old items in the region and making them available for those in need.Charity volunteer Kenneth Hill said: “The group has had obstacles to overcome with the council planning.“But the building is now to be opened as a furniture recycling charity.“It should be open fully in the next few weeks.”A council spokesman said: “The traders within the property have the necessary second hand dealer licenses and a building warrant has been issued to carry out the physical works to the structure.“As yet the owners have not submitted a completion certificate on these works.“Once that has been done an inspection will be carried out to ensure compliance.”

title: dundee boss neil hails the impact of midfield main man lewis spence
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann has hailed the impact of Lewis Spence, saying he’s embraced the responsibility of being the “main man” in his midfield.The 22-year-old former Dunfermline man was the Dens gaffer’s first signing last summer, snapped up under the noses of then-Championship side Brechin City.And despite missing large chunks of last season with injury, Neil is delighted to see Spence make the step up to the top flight so well.“Spence has been terrific since he’s come in,” he said.“I think he’s really enjoyed the responsibility of being in there and because we’re playing with a bit of control in front of the back four, it’s his natural game.“He’s been great.“I always knew what Spence was capable of – it was about getting him to believe it.“He’s a winner but he’s jumped levels to come into the Premiership last summer and I thought he had some exceptional performances.“This year he has come back pre-season and has been given an opportunity in there to be the main man in front of the back four because Glen Kamara generally stole a lot of the limelight in that position last year.“Spence has gone in there and done really well.“We’ve been strong in the middle of the park, other areas we clearly need to add to.”There was a worry Spence would be ruled out for today’s League Cup last-16 clash with Ayr United after picking up a knock on his ankle last week.However, he has declared himself fit for action (see left) and is expected to retain his place today against the Honest Men.

title: dundee colts and united drawn at home in irn bru cup
story: Dundee Colts and Dundee United have been awarded home ties in the Irn Bru Cup.The second round draw has seen the Dark Blues youngsters host Motherwell Colts.Meanwhile United will welcome Alloa Athletic to Tannadice. It&#8217s the fourth cup competition in a row the Tangerines have been drawn against Jim Goodwin&#8217s men.Dundee United dramatically came from two goals down to beat St Johnstone 3-2, with a Paul McMullan goal in the dying minutes securing their place in the competition.The previous night, the Dundee Colts needed to beat Hibs Colts on penalties after it finished 2-2 after 90 minutes.The Dark Blues &#8211 who sported their away top &#8211 won 4-3 in the shootout.The games will take place on the weekend of September 8 or 9.

title: dundee defender jefferies over the moon to grab his first senior goal in hibernian clash
story: Centre-back Dan Jefferies was “over the moon” to have grabbed his first senior goal as Dundee Colts edged out Hibs Colts on penalties in the Irn-Bru Cup on Tuesday night.The Welsh defender leapt highest late on to nod in the equaliser to make it 2-2 and force spot-kicks which the young Dark Blues won 4-3 to book their place in the second round.Being a senior competition, the goal counts in the record books and Jefferies is hoping it won’t be the last.He said: “I’m obviously over the moon about the goal!“I’m speechless – I don’t know what to say after scoring a goal because I don’t do it very often but I’m just happy to help the boys.“We’re absolutely delighted to get through.“We’re disappointed we didn’t finish it in the 90 minutes but the boys dug in and then stepped up for the pens.”Coach Jimmy Boyle was delighted to see his side “stick to their guns” in the victory over Hibs.Tom Bradbury’s back-post header from Jack Lambert’s cross gave the young Dees the lead before Fraser Murray replied in the first half.The visitors then took the lead as Sean Mackie smashed past goalkeeper Sam Jackson after he’d made a string of saves.Jefferies made it a centre-half double for his side, heading in with five minutes left to set up penalties.Jackson made two saves to give Bradbury the chance to send his side through to the second round, which he did emphatically.Coach Jimmy said: “When you look at our team, we’re a lot younger than them. We knew it would be a good game, we know what Hibs are about, they are a very good team.“I enjoyed the way we played, some of the stuff in the first half was excellent but we know they have quality and put us under pressure. I’m pleased we stuck to our guns and we got what we deserved.”There was plenty to be happy about including an impressive display from winger Cammy Dow.Jimmy said: “Sam Jackson did great, he’s a confident big boy and I thought Cammy Dow was excellent – he’s a massive Dundee fan as well, which is great.”

title: dundee man drove without licence
story: Bruce Taylor, 35, of Gourdie Road, admitted that he drove his car without supervision or a licence authorising him to drive, being the holder of a provisional licence, at Fintry Drive on May 6.He also admitted that he used a motor vehicle without a valid insurance policy at the same place on the same date.He was fined £100 for the licence infringement and £300 for driving without insurance.

title: dundee pub defends decision to turn away pro independence supporters at dundee march
story: A Dundee pub has said its decision to turn away pro-independence marchers at the weekend was in a bid to &#8220prevent disagreements&#8221.The Boozy Cow on Roseangle has come under fire on social media after participants of the All Under One Banner in the city on Saturday are said to have been refused entry.A number of folk said to have been clad in Saltires, SNP badges and pro-independence attire claimed to have been denied entry, prompting a boycott of the eatery.It comes after thousands descended on the city for the rally which started at Baxter Park and ended at Magdalen Green with speeches and music.Responding to criticism, a statement from the burger chain claimed it acted on police and licensing standards advice.It read: &#8220Boozy Cow staff were&#8230 advised that we should put in extra security measures as there was a projected turnout of over 16,000 people.&#8220These public bodies suggested we enact a policy to refuse patrons carrying colours to prevent disagreements. We complied with this advice as we would anytime Police Scotland or Licensing Standards make a request. &#8220The Boozy Cow would never refuse service on the basis of religion, gender, sexual orientation or political beliefs. The policy was put in place to comply with the advice we were given by public bodies. We complied and cannot comment on why some other businesses decided not to take this advice.&#8221It went on to state that the restaurant, which donates its profits to charity, did not carry out the action as a &#8220personal or politically motivated&#8221 action.The statement added: &#8220We hope people understand why we took this decision and we want you to come back to our establishment in the future.&#8221

title: dundee set to announce signing of finnish striker benjamin kallman
story: Dundee are set to announce the signing of Finnish striker Benjamin Kallman.It’s understood the 20-year-old Inter Turku forward will sign on an initial loan deal.The Finnish international has scored eight goals in 20 league matches for Inter Turku this season and featured in a friendly against Jordan for the national side after being called up for the first time – along with Dundee’s Glen Kamara – at the start of this year.Dens gaffer Neil McCann has identified Kallman as the man to help solve his side’s goal problem and he is known to be a strong, skilful forward.It is expected he will arrive in Dundee later today for a medical and will train with his new team-mates.He scored nine goals in his debut season last year as Inter Turku finished ninth and scored twice for the Finnish U/21 side in a recent win over the Faroe Islands.&nbsp

title: dundees liquid nightclub to reopen under new name after takeover by owner of city nightspot
story: A popular nightclub that closed earlier this year is set to reopen under new ownership and with a brand new name.Liquid nightclub, on Ward Road, will be transformed into Carbon and Kush in time for students returning to the city in early September.The club has been taken over by the owner of Industry nightclub Tahir Ramzan (pictured), who promised the venue would have three separate music rooms, a VIP room and a garden terrace.Mr Ramzam said: “We will have three rooms of music to chose from and a new garden terrace to socialise in.“Our VIP room will feel like a separate club even though it’s in the same building.“We also have fantastic promoters and DJs on board and hope people love what Carbon and Kush has to offer.”Liquid closed suddenly in March, with the club’s Milton Keynes-based operator Deltic saying the decision had been taken because “the night-time economy in the city is continuing to decline”.After taking over the club’s lease for the next 12 months, Mr Ramzan said: “It’s an exciting time for Dundee businesses to look carefully at what customers expect from an emerging city.“Nightife is very important for a thriving city that wants to attract people from outwith the area.“However, nightclubs and the late-night trade have gone through a difficult time lately as trends have changed with many people choosing to stay at home.“But to meet people you still need to go out and talk and it’s our job to create these environments.”Tony Cochrane, owner of Club Tropicana on the same street, said: “We knew something was happening as we know the owners of Liquid. The more the merrier for the street.”

title: dundee united kid glass working to keep things simple
story: In football the most difficult skill is usually finding the piece of magic in the final third that leads to goals.But, for fast-emerging Dundee United kid Declan Glass, it’s the simple side of the game he’s working hard at to add to his unquestioned abilities.The 18-year-old’s form was one of the big positives of the pre-season and a difficult Betfred Cup campaign for the Tangerines.So much so, in fact, some Arabs feel, despite his tender years, he should already be commanding a regular starting place in Csaba Laszlo’s side.The manager, though, has already expressed his determination not to heap too much pressure on the teenage attacker and risk burning him out.There are aspects of his game Csaba wants Glass to work on and the player himself has taken that on board.And one area where he knows he can improve in is, at times, playing the easy pass that keeps possession.“Sometimes I do need to do things simpler. I complicate my game sometimes but I’m working on just playing it simple and that’s what the gaffer and (assistant manager) Laurie Ellis want me to do.“They stress to me I have to play it simple at times and then do the magic when I can.”Not that it’s an easy process and Glass admits when he’s on the pitch he wants to be involved at the sharp end, doing the things that help win games.“I like to create chances and I really love to get shots in on the goal, it’s what my game is about.“I’m an attacking player and I like to excite but you can’t always do that and sometimes it is about keeping things simple and doing it for the team.”As those words show, this is a young man who does not lack confidence in his own ability but he’s also one who gives an honest assessment of his performances.For instance, while he was delighted to have played his part in a young United line-up that battled back from two goals down to beat St Johnstone’s U/21s in the Betfred Cup on Wednesday night, he was far from completely satisfied with his work.“It was a brilliant result, all the boys worked really hard to come from two behind like we did.“Obviously, the experienced players helped us a lot but I thought the young boys, including myself, dug in and we battled and battled.“St Johnstone were no mugs and I thought they really impressed so it was good to get on top of them by the end.“I know I wasn’t at my best but, like all the boys, I dug in and helped get the result.“I was maybe trying too hard at times for the killer pass or maybe trying to shoot too early.“Sometimes things don’t come off on the park but I still worked hard and helped the team and that’s what you have to make sure you do.”As he keeps grafting towards making the breakthrough in the first team on a regular basis, Glass was delighted by the victory, not least because it means there will be further opportunities to show he is ready.“This cup is a chance to get 90 minutes and, if I’m not playing in the league, I need to get games somewhere.“If it’s in the Irn-Bru Cup it’s better for me and the other boys, because they are very competitive, like league games.“You want to win them, both teams do, and it gives you the chance to show up well.“We want to do well in it and I think we can.“I thought our fitness was a big factor against St Johnstone.“We had a hard pre-season and I think we got the benefits of that against St Johnstone because we finished the game strongly and looked the fitter team.”

title: dundee woman louise can wed in style after winning tele competition
story: A bride-to-be will walk down the aisle in style thanks to the Evening .Louise McDonald, 22, from Charleston, was named the winner of our Wed in Style competition during the Scottish Wedding Directory’s fashion show, held at DCT Media’s Meadowside HQ.Tele readers were invited to collect points in an innovatve fruit machine- style competition which used digital technology to create tens of thousands of unique gamecards.Louise topped the list of five finalists to win a Justin Alexander gown worth up to £1,500, sponsored by Alison Kirk Bridal, kilts for fiance Graeme Boyd and five groomsmen courtesy of Kilthire Company and her carriage for the big day in the shape of a classic vintage car, sponsored by the Lovely Wedding Car Company.She said she was “in total shock” after discovering she had won the big prize.“I’m over the moon. I started shaking when I found out,” Louise added.“Graeme would finish work at 9.30pm and I would tell him to run to the shops to get more papers.”Graeme proposed on a Ferris wheel in Malaga in October last year.“I’m scared of heights,” said Louise. “He said he wanted me to face my fears.”The couple have set a date of February 20 2020 and joining them on the day will be their children Ryan, 3, and one-year-old Calli.Louise said: “Graeme chose the date because it’s memorable and he won’t forget the anniversary.”Runners-up in the competition were Wendie Norrie, Sarah McDougall, Evelyn Raitt and Sarah Hendy,and they all win an overnight stay at Hotel du Vin and £100 of vouchers to spend in its bistro.Tele editor Andrew Kellock said: “Congratulations to Louise and Graeme and a big thank you to all our sponsors in what was a fantastic competition.”

title: folk with lampshades seen rummaging through bins on dundee street to find goods to sell
story: Residents in a street blighted by litter believe bin raiders are rifling through their rubbish looking for dumped goods to sell on.Photos taken on Dudhope Street in Coldside show torn rubbish bags strewn across the street, with neighbours claiming they have seen people going through the bins at night.Caitlin Nelson, 20, said she moved back to the street in April after growing up in the area and the litter looters have been seen every night since.She said: “I have seen them walking down the street with lampshades and going through the food bins.“From my window I have watched people going through the bins every night and I’ve phoned the police about it a couple of times.”Caitlin said the scavengers usually appear around 6pm every night.She added: “I threw cat litter in the bin and they took everything but that.“I have seen them go through the bins trying to find something to sell.“The police have said they don’t know anything about it and unless they have seen it, they can’t do anything about it.”Caitlin said the problems started after people put rubbish on top of the bins for collection.“Apparently people used to leave stuff on top of the bins and they would take that. It all started from that,” she said.“The council has said it is a matter for the police to deal with.”A Dundee City Council spokeswoman said: “We are aware of the situation and are taking the appropriate action.“We would also encourage residents to use the correct bins to recycle appropriate materials.”A Police Scotland spokesman said officers were called to Dudhope Street after a resident raised concerns about two people acting suspiciously near a bin recess.“The area was searched but they were not traced,” he added.

title: manhunt after two dundee bookies and local shop targeted in armed raids

title: meekings grateful to dundee boss mccann for captaincy honour
story: New Dundee captain Josh Meekings has thanked under-fire boss Neil McCann for trusting him with the armband.McCann has confirmed the former Inverness defender will lead out the Dens Park side for the remainder of the season after trying out eight other potential candidates during pre-season.The 25-year-old Englishman says he is grateful for the honour and has vowed to repay McCann &#8211 who is coming under increasing pressure from fans following his side&#8217s shock Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United on Saturday &#8211 with improved performances.He said: &#8220I&#8217m grateful for the manager for pulling me in to tell me I&#8217m going to captain the side. It&#8217s a great honour.&#8220It was a difficult period at the start last year. I came to the club without any (firm offer of a contract) but the manager took me on and said he had trust in me to come into the side if I carried on working hard and I&#8217ve done that.&#8220Last season was about getting some game time but this year I&#8217m looking to properly kick on, play some good football and help the team move forward.&#8220There is a number of boys who are captain material in the squad. The armband has been passed around in pre-season, everybody has their own ideas on it.&#8220But it&#8217s the manager&#8217s decision in the end and I&#8217m grateful to chosen me to do it.&#8221

title: some team is going to take a battering from us soon says dundee midfielder spence
story: Straight-Talking Lewis Spence insists it’s only a matter of time before Dundee’s form in front of goal turns around, saying “some team is going to take a battering” from them soon.The 22-year-old is hoping that’s today as Ayr United come calling in the Betfred Cup last 16 at Dens Park.Although he’s backing his team-mates to start putting away the chances they are creating, he knows just how tough the Honest Men will be to get past.Dundee will have to keep an eye on dangerman striker Lawrence Shankland.He said: “It’s going to come, our luck has to change some time because we are getting the chances.“I think some team is going to take a battering soon, we’ll take three or four off somebody, and hopefully that might be this weekend.“It’ll be a really tough game, though, Ayr are no pushovers, I know a few of their players and they are a decent team.“They play some good stuff and have goalscorers in their team so it’ll be tough.“They won League One so they’ve come up with confidence and have goals in their team, boys that can put it in the net.“They’ll come here with confidence but we’re confident we can get the job done if we apply ourselves the right way professionally.“I’ve always said we want a cup run here to give the fans something back and this is a great draw for us.“It’ll be difficult but we win that and we’re in the quarters and a decent draw can see you to the semis at Hampden.“However, we need to take care of Ayr first – we can’t look past them.”Spence was an injury doubt for this one after he was subbed in last weekend’s 1-0 defeat at home to Aberdeen with an ankle knock. He says, though, coming off was just a precaution after needing surgery on the same ankle last season.He said: “It was nothing too serious. I had a shot and rolled my ankle a bit and I’ve had previous with it, so it was a bit of a worry at the time. However, a good bit of rest and the physio saw it. I’ve trained this week and it’s good. I just need to keep an eye on it.”Now would be an unfortunate time for Spence to be ruled out of action after some impressive displays in the early-season games and particularly due to the level of competition in the position now at Dens Park.“Last year there were a lot of centre-mids but again this year we’re very strong there, one of the strongest areas in the team,” he added.“I think that’s good because it keeps everyone on their toes, you can’t slack because there will be somebody else to take your place.“I believe in my ability and I’ve worked hard over the summer, worked hard in pre-season, too.“Obviously, I’ve been in the position but Glen Kamara is to come back and you’ve got Adil Nabi, Paul McGowan, Elton Ngwatala and Kharl Madianga, so there’s a lot of competition in there. I think throughout the season it will be getting rotated round and, hopefully, I can be in that team.“I think I’ve done OK so far. It’s still early but I want to keep this up through the whole season.“Last year I played well in stages and then got injured so I want to play consistently every week, play as much as I can, and obviously help the team climb the table.”And the way to do that will be to start finding the net, something Spence is adamant that’ll change soon.“I think our luck will turn around.“We have to put some of these chances away, we all know that, but the main thing is we are creating chances.“One day it is going to click, something is just missing at the moment but we all believe in the guys up front to go and do it.”

title: tonight matthew starz in thir ehs set to play in caird hall for final time
story: Dozens of headline acts – including “Tina Turner” and “Bruce Springsteen” – could be set to play at the Caird Hall for the final time next month.For the past eight years, amateur performers – including a number of Dundee City Council employees – have been disappearing behind the curtain and re-emerging as their celebrity alter egos for Starz In Thir Ehs.As the name suggests, the show is a homage to the much-loved TV show Stars in Their Eyes.Presented by Matthew Kelly, the show entertained prime-time Saturday night TV audiences for nearly two decades until it was cancelled in 2006 – and Starz in Thir Ehs has continued that tradition.Ron Whyte, of Stage 1 Theatre Company, said this year’s cast members are making the final preparations for the show which takes place on Thursday September 6.He said: “We’ve been doing this show for the last seven or eight years.“It started off with employees from the social work department at Dundee City Council and the cast has grown from there.”Formed in 1994, the theatre company has helped to raise more than £50,000 for local charities through performances, including the Starz In Thir Ehs shows.But audiences numbers have dwindled in recent years and Ron said next year’s show might have to be held at a smaller venue.Ron, from Douglas, added: “The show used to attract 800-900 people.“The numbers have gone down recently so it may well be the last time we decide to run the event in the Caird Hall.“We’ve got Bruce Springsteen playing this year as well as Kenny Rogers and Belinda Carlisle.“The show always went down well and we had great audience participation.“Since we started more than 20 years ago we must have raised £50,000 for local charities.“If it is a case that this is the last time at the Caird Hall, I’m sure we’ll go out with a bang.”Tickets for the show are available from the Dundee Box Office.
